{{Taxonbar|from=Q491934}}
[[Category:Amiiformes]] [[Category:Fish of North America]] [[Category:Freshwater fish by continent|North America]] [[Category:Fish of the Great Lakes]] [[Category:Living fossils]] [[Category:Freshwater fish of the Southeastern United States]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:Fish described in 1766]]

'''Brainstem death''' is a clinical syndrome defined by the absence of reflexes with pathways through the [[brainstem]]—the "stalk" of the brain, which connects the [[spinal cord]] to the [[mid-brain]], [[cerebellum]] and [[cerebral hemispheres]]—in a deeply comatose, [[Medical ventilator|ventilator]]-dependent patient. Identification of this state carries a very grave [[prognosis]] for survival; cessation of [[Cardiac cycle|heartbeat]] often occurs within a few days although it may continue for weeks if intensive support is maintained.<ref name ="AMRC">A Code of Practice for the Diagnosis and Confirmation of Death. Academy of Medical Royal Colleges, 70 Wimpole Street, London, 2008</ref>
In the [[United Kingdom]], the formal diagnosis of brainstem death by the procedure laid down in the official Code of Practice<ref name ="AMRC"/> permits the diagnosis and certification of [[death]] on the premise that a person is dead when consciousness and the ability to breathe are permanently lost, regardless of continuing life in the body and parts of the brain, and that death of the brainstem alone is sufficient to produce this state.<ref name = "Roy">Criteria for the diagnosis of brain stem death. J Roy Coll Physns of London 1995;29:381–2</ref>
This concept of brainstem death is also accepted as grounds for pronouncing death for legal purposes in [[India]]<ref>The Transplantation of Human Organs Act, 1994. Act No.42 of 1994. s. 2</ref> and [[Trinidad and Tobago|Trinidad & Tobago]].<ref>Human Tissue Transplant Act 2000. s. 19(1)</ref> Elsewhere in the world the concept upon which the certification of death on neurological grounds is based is that of permanent cessation of all function in all parts of the brain—[[Brain death|whole brain death]]—with which the British concept should not be confused. The [[United States]]' [[President's Council on Bioethics]] made it clear, for example, in its White Paper of December 2008, that the British concept and clinical criteria are not considered sufficient for the diagnosis of death in the United States of America.<ref>Controversies in the determination of death. A White Paper by the President's Council on Bioethics, Washington, DC. p 66</ref>
==Evolution of diagnostic criteria==
The United Kingdom (UK) criteria were first published by the Conference of Medical Royal Colleges (with advice from the Transplant Advisory Panel) in 1976, as prognostic guidelines.<ref name = "CMR1976">Conference of Medical Royal Colleges and their Faculties in the UK. BMJ 1976;2:1187–8</ref> They were drafted in response to a perceived need for guidance in the management of deeply comatose patients with severe [[brain damage]] who were being kept alive by [[Mechanical ventilation|mechanical ventilators]] but showing no signs of recovery. The Conference sought "to establish diagnostic criteria of such rigour that on their fulfilment the mechanical ventilator can be switched off, in the secure knowledge that there is no possible chance of recovery". The published criteria—negative responses to bedside tests of some reflexes with pathways through the brainstem and a specified challenge to the brainstem respiratory centre, with caveats about exclusion of [[endocrine]] influences, [[Metabolism|metabolic]] factors and drug effects—were held to be "sufficient to distinguish between those patients who retain the functional capacity to have a chance of even partial recovery and those where no such possibility exists". Recognition of that state required the withdrawal of fruitless further [[Life support|artificial support]] so that death might be allowed to occur, thus "sparing relatives from the further [[emotional trauma]] of sterile hope".<ref name ="CMR1976"/>
In 1979, the Conference of Medical Royal Colleges promulgated its conclusion that identification of the state defined by those same criteria—then thought sufficient for a diagnosis of brain death—"means that the patient is dead"<ref name ="CMJ1979">Conference of Medical Royal Colleges and their Faculties in the UK. BMJ 1979;1:332.</ref> [[Death certificate|Death certification]] on those criteria has continued in the United Kingdom (where there is no statutory legal definition of death) since that time, particularly for [[organ transplantation]] purposes, although the conceptual basis for that use has changed.
In 1995, after a review by a Working Group of the [[Royal College of Physicians]] of [[London]], the Conference of Medical Royal Colleges<ref name = "Roy"/> formally adopted the "more correct" term for the syndrome, "brainstem death"—championed by [[Chris Pallis|Pallis]] in a set of 1982 articles in the ''[[British Medical Journal]]''<ref name = "Pallis">Pallis, C. From Brain Death to Brain Stem Death, BMJ, 285, November 1982</ref>—and advanced a new definition of human death as the basis for equating this syndrome with the death of the person. The suggested new definition of death was the "irreversible loss of the capacity for consciousness, combined with irreversible loss of the capacity to breathe". It was stated that the irreversible cessation of brainstem function will produce this state and "therefore brainstem death is equivalent to the death of the individual".<ref name = "Roy"/>
==Diagnosis==
In the UK, the formal rules for the diagnosis of brainstem death have undergone only minor modifications since they were first published<ref name = "CMR1976"/> in 1976. The most recent revision of the UK's Department of Health Code of Practice governing use of that procedure for the diagnosis of death<ref name ="AMRC"/> reaffirms the preconditions for its consideration. These are:
#There should be no doubt that the patient's condition – deeply comatose, unresponsive and requiring [[artificial ventilation]]—is due to irreversible brain damage of known cause. #There should be no evidence that this state is due to [[depressant]] drugs. #Primary [[hypothermia]] as the cause of unconsciousness must have been excluded, and #Potentially reversible circulatory, metabolic and endocrine disturbances likewise. #Potentially reversible causes of [[apnoea]] (dependence on the ventilator), such as [[muscle relaxant]]s and cervical cord injury, must be excluded.
With these pre-conditions satisfied, the definitive criteria are:
#Fixed pupils which do not respond to sharp changes in the intensity of [[incident light]]. #No [[corneal reflex]]. #Absent [[oculovestibular reflex]]es – no eye movements following the slow injection of at least 50ml of ice-cold water into each ear in turn (the [[caloric reflex test]]). #No response to supraorbital pressure. #No [[cough reflex]] to bronchial stimulation or gagging response to pharyngeal stimulation. #No observed respiratory effort in response to disconnection of the ventilator for long enough (typically 5 minutes) to ensure elevation of the arterial partial pressure of [[carbon dioxide]] to at least 6.0 kPa (6.5 kPa in patients with chronic carbon dioxide retention). Adequate [[Oxygenation (medicine)|oxygenation]] is ensured by pre-oxygenation and diffusion oxygenation during the disconnection (so the brainstem respiratory centre is not challenged by the ultimate, anoxic, drive stimulus). This test—the apnoea test—is dangerous – and may prove lethal.<ref name ="Coimbra87"/><ref>Coimbra CG. The apnea test – a bedside lethal 'disaster' to avoid a legal 'disaster' in the operating room. In Finis Vitae – is brain death still life? pp.113–45</ref><ref>Saposnik G et al. Problems associated with the apnea test in the diagnosis of brain death. Neurology India 2004;52:342–45</ref><ref>Yingying S et al. Diagnosis of brain death : confirmatory tests after clinical test. Chin Med J 2014;127:1272–77</ref>
Two doctors, of specified status and experience, are required to act together to diagnose death on these criteria and the tests must be repeated after "a short period of time ... to allow return of the patient's [[arterial blood gas]]es and baseline parameters to the pre-test state". These criteria for the diagnosis of death are not applicable to infants below the age of two months.
==Prognosis and management==
With due regard for the cause of the coma, and the rapidity of its onset, testing for the purpose of diagnosing death on brainstem death grounds may be delayed beyond the stage where brainstem reflexes may be absent only temporarily – because the [[cerebral blood flow]] is inadequate to support synaptic function although there is still sufficient blood flow to keep [[brain cell]]s alive <ref name ="Coimbra87">Coimbra CG. Implications of ischemic penumbra for the diagnosis of brain death. Brazilian Journal of Medical and Biological Research 1999;32:1479–87</ref> and capable of recovery. There has recently been renewed interest in the possibility of neuronal protection during this phase by use of moderate hypothermia and by correction of the [[neuroendocrine]] abnormalities commonly seen in this early stage.<ref>Coimbra CG. Are 'brain dead' (or 'brain stem dead') patients neurologically recoverable? In Finis Vitae—'brain death' is not true death. Eds. De Mattei R, Byrne PA. Life Guardian Foundation, Oregon, Ohio, 2009, pp. 313–378</ref>
Published studies of patients meeting the criteria for brainstem death or whole brain death – the American standard which includes brainstem death diagnosed by similar means – record that even if ventilation is continued after diagnosis, the heart stops beating within only a few hours or days.<ref>Pallis C, Harley DH. ABC of brain stem death. BMJ Publishing Group, 1996, p.30</ref> However, there have been some very long-term survivals<ref>Shewmon DA. 'Brain body' disconnection : implications for the theoretical basis of 'brain death'. In Finis Vitae – is brain death still life? Ed. De Mattei R. Consiglio Nazionale delle Richerche. Rubbettino, 2006, pp. 211–250</ref> and it is noteworthy that expert management can maintain the bodily functions of [[pregnant]] brain dead women for long enough to bring them to term.<ref>Powner DJ, Bernstein IM. Extended somatic support for pregnant women after brain death. Crit Care Med 2003;31:1241–49</ref>
==Criticism==
The diagnostic criteria were originally published for the purpose of identifying a clinical state associated with a fatal prognosis (see above). The change of use, in the UK, to criteria for the diagnosis of death itself was protested from the first.<ref name ="Evans-C">Evans DW, Lum LC. Cardiac transplantation. Lancet 1980;1:933–4</ref><ref>Evans DW, Lum LC. Brain death. Lancet 1980;2:1022</ref> The initial basis for the change of use was the claim that satisfaction of the criteria sufficed for the diagnosis of the death of the brain as a whole, despite the persistence of demonstrable activity in parts of the brain.<ref name="Beyond brain death">Evans DW. The demise of 'brain death' in Britain. In Beyond brain death—the case against brain based criteria for human death. Eds. Potts M, Byrne PA, Nilges RG. Kluwer Academic Publishers, 2006, pp. 139–158 </ref> In 1995, that claim was abandoned<ref name =CMJ1979/> and the diagnosis of death (acceptable for legal purposes in the UK in the context of organ procurement for transplantation) by the specified testing of brainstem functions was based on a new definition of death, viz. the permanent loss of the capacity for consciousness and spontaneous breathing. There are doubts that this concept is generally understood and accepted and that the specified testing is stringent enough to determine that state. It is, however, associated with substantial risk of exacerbating the brain damage and even causing the death of the apparently dying patient so tested (see "the apnoea test" above). This raises ethical problems which seem not to have been addressed.
It has been argued that sound scientific support is lacking for the claim that the specified purely bedside tests have the power to diagnose true and total death of the brainstem, the necessary condition for the assumption of permanent loss of the intrinsically untestable consciousness-arousal function of those elements of the [[reticular formation]] which lie within the brainstem (there are elements also within the higher brain).<ref name="Beyond brain death"/> Knowledge of this arousal system is based upon the findings from animal experiments<ref name ="Moruzzi73"/><ref>Ward AA. The relationship between the bulbar-reticular suppressor region and the EEG. Clin Neurophysiol 1949;1:120</ref><ref>Lindsley DB et al. Effect upon the EEG of acute injury to the brain stem activating system. EEG Clin Neurophysiol 1949;1:475–8627</ref> as illuminated by pathological studies in humans.<ref name ="Parvizi">Parvizi J, Damasio AR. Neuroanatomical correlates of brainstem coma. Brain 2003;126:1524–36</ref> The current neurological consensus is that the arousal of consciousness depends upon reticular components which reside in the midbrain, [[diencephalon]] and [[pons]].<ref>Textbook of clinical neurology, 2nd Edn. Ed. Goetz CG. Elsevier Science, 2003</ref><ref>Bleck TP. In Textbook of clinical neurology, 3rd Edn. Ed. Goetz CG. Elsevier Science, 2007</ref> It is said that the midbrain reticular formation may be viewed as a driving centre for the higher structures, loss of which produces a state in which the [[Cerebral cortex|cortex]] appears, on the basis of electroencephalographic (EEG) studies, to be awaiting the command or ability to function. The role of diencephalic (higher brain) involvement is stated to be uncertain and we are reminded that the arousal system is best regarded as a physiological rather than a precise anatomical entity. There should, perhaps, also be a caveat about possible arousal mechanisms involving the first and second [[cranial nerve]]s (serving sight and smell) which are not tested when diagnosing brainstem death but which were described in cats in 1935 and 1938.<ref name ="Moruzzi73">G, Magoun HW. Brain stem reticular formation and activation of the EEG. Electroencephalog Clin neurophysiol 1949;1:455–73</ref> In humans, light flashes have been observed to disturb the sleep-like EEG activity persisting after the loss of all brainstem reflexes and of spontaneous respiration.<ref>Zwarts MJ, Kornips FHM. Clinical brainstem death with preserved electroencephalographic activity and visual evoked response. Arch Neurol 2001;58:1010</ref>
There is also concern about the permanence of consciousness loss, based on studies in cats, dogs and monkeys which recovered consciousness days or weeks after being rendered comatose by brainstem ablation and on human studies of [[brainstem stroke syndrome]] raising thoughts about the "plasticity" of the nervous system.<ref name ="Parvizi"/> Other theories of consciousness place more stress on the thalamocortical system.<ref>Tononi G. An information integration theory of consciousness. BMC Neuroscience 2004;5:42</ref> Perhaps the most objective statement to be made is that consciousness is not currently understood. That being so, proper caution must be exercised in accepting a diagnosis of its permanent loss before all cerebral blood flow has permanently ceased.
The ability to breathe spontaneously depends upon functioning elements in the [[Medulla oblongata|medulla]] – the 'respiratory centre'. In the UK, establishing a neurological diagnosis of death involves challenging this centre with the strong stimulus offered by an unusually high concentration of carbon dioxide in the arterial blood, but it is not challenged by the more powerful drive stimulus provided by [[Hypoxia (medical)|anoxia]] – although the effect of that ultimate stimulus is sometimes seen after final disconnection of the ventilator in the form of [[Agonal respiration|agonal gasps]].
No testing of testable brain stem functions such as oesophageal and cardiovascular regulation is specified in the UK Code of Practice for the diagnosis of death on neurological grounds. There is published evidence<ref>Hall GM et al. Hypothalamic-pituitary function in the 'brain dead' patient. Lancet 1980;2:1259</ref><ref>Wetzel RC et al. Hemodynamic responses in brain dead organ donor patients. Anesthesia and Analgesia 1985;64:125–8</ref><ref>Pennefather SH, Dark JH, Bullock RE. Haemodynamic responses to surgery in brain-dead organ donors. Anaesthesia 1993;48:1034–38</ref> strongly suggestive of the persistence of brainstem [[blood pressure]] control in [[Organ donation|organ donors]].
A small minority of medical practitioners working in the UK have argued that neither requirement of the UK Health Department's Code of Practice basis for the equation of brainstem death with death is satisfied by its current diagnostic protocol<ref name ="AMRC"/> and that in terms of its ability to diagnose de facto brainstem death it falls far short.

{{Infobox royalty | name = Princess Charlotte | image = Jacques-Louis David - The Sisters Zénaïde and Charlotte Bonaparte - Google Art Project.jpg | caption = Zénaïde and Charlotte Bonaparte in 1821,
by [[Jacques-Louis David]] | house = [[House of Bonaparte|Bonaparte]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1802|10|31|df=y}} | birth_place = Paris, [[French First Republic|France]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1839|3|2|1802|10|31|df=y}} | death_place = [[Sarzana]], [[Kingdom of Sardinia]] | full name = Charlotte Napoléone Bonaparte | place of burial = [[Basilica of Santa Croce, Florence|Basilica of Santa Croce]],
[[Florence]], Italy | father = [[Joseph Bonaparte]] | mother = [[Julie Clary]] | spouse = [[Napoleon Louis Bonaparte]] }} [[File:Bordentown Zenaide Bonaparte 002.jpg|thumb|View of Princess Charlotte's former residence, [[Bordentown, New Jersey]]]] '''Charlotte Napoléone Bonaparte''' (31 October 1802 – 2 March 1839) was the daughter of [[Joseph Bonaparte]], the older brother of Emperor [[Napoleon I]], and [[Julie Clary]]. Her mother was the sister of [[Désirée Clary]], Napoleon's first love. Charlotte [[Cousin marriage|married her first cousin]] [[Napoleon Louis Bonaparte|Napoleon Louis]], the second son of [[Louis Bonaparte]] and [[Hortense de Beauharnais]]. She studied engraving and lithography in Paris with the artist [[Louis Léopold Robert]], who is reputed to have fallen in love with her. ==Early life== After her father was deposed in 1813 he moved to America and purchased "Point Breeze", an estate on the [[Delaware River]] near [[Bordentown, New Jersey]]. His palatial house was filled with paintings and sculpture by such luminaries as [[Jacques-Louis David]], [[Antonio Canova]], [[Peter Paul Rubens]], and [[Titian]] (Tiziano Vecelli). The surrounding park of {{convert|1800|acre|km2}} included landscaped gardens. Joseph Bonaparte played host to many of the national’s wealthiest and most cultivated citizens, and his art collection played a crucial role in transmitting high European taste to America. ==Artist== Charlotte, known as the Countess de Survilliers, lived with her father in New Jersey from December 1821 to August 1824. While there she sketched numerous landscapes including Passaic Falls, her father's "Point Breeze" estate, the town of [[Lebanon, New Jersey]], and others, some of which were engraved for the book "Picturesque American Scenes" by Joubert. Extant landscape drawings by her include [[Great Falls (Passaic River)|Passaic Falls]], a view near [[Tuckerton, New Jersey]], and [[Schooley's Mountain]]. She also painted portraits (Cora Monges, 1822; Emilie Lacoste, 1823) and exhibited her work at the [[Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts]]. ==Portraits== Charlotte, her sister Zénaide (1801–1854), and their mother were painted by the French artist [[François Gérard]], while their mother was Queen of Spain. Another French artist, the well-known [[Jacques-Louis David]], painted a portrait of the two sisters; it shows them reading a letter from Philadelphia sent by their father. ==Death== Charlotte reportedly died in childbirth, aged 36.{{Citation needed|date=December 2007}} Her tomb is in the Basilica of Santa Croce, Florence, Italy, and it says (paraphrased): Born Oct. 31, 1802, died 1839. ==Titles== * Princess Charlotte Bonaparte, Infanta of Spain ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1 = background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2 = background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3 = background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4 = background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5 = background-color: #9fe; |1 = 1. '''Charlotte Napoléone Bonaparte''' |2 = 2. [[Joseph Bonaparte|Giuseppe Napoleone Buonaparte]] |3 = 3. [[Julie Clary|Marie Julie Clary]] |4 = 4. [[Carlo Buonaparte|Carlo Maria Buonaparte]] |5 = 5. [[Letizia Ramolino|Maria Letizia Ramolino]] |6 = 6. [[François Clary]] |7 = 7. Françoise Rose Somis |8 = 8. [[Giuseppe Maria Buonaparte]] |9 = 9. Maria Saveria Paravicini |10 = 10. Giovanni Geronimo Ramolino |11 = 11. Angela Maria Pietrasanta |12= 12. Joseph Clary |13= 13. Françoise Agnès Ammoric |14= 14. Joseph Ignace Somis |15= 15. Catherine Rose Soucheiron |16 = 16. Sebastiano Nicola Buonaparte |17 = 17. Maria Anna Tusoli |18 = 18. Giuseppe Maria Paravicini |19 = 19. Maria Angela Salineri |20 = 20. Giovanni Agostino Ramolino |21 = 21. Angela Maria Peri |22 = 22. Giuseppe Maria Pietrasanta |23 = 23. Maria Giuseppa Malerba |24= 24. Jacques Clary |25= 25. Catherine Barosse |26= 26. François Ammoric |27= 27. Jeanne Boisson |28= 28. Jean Louis Somis |29= 29. Françoise Bouchard |30= 30. François Soucheiron |31= 31. Anne Cautier }} ==Sources== {{Commons category|Charlotte Napoléone Bonaparte}} * E. Benezit, Dictionnaire critique et documentaire des Peintres, Sculpteurs, Dessinateurs et Graveurs (1966), vol. 1, p. 754, and vol. 7, p. 279. * Patricia Tyson Stroud, The Man Who Had Been King: The American Exile of Napoleon’s Brother Joseph (Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2005), pp. 88–113. * William H. Gerdts, Painting and Sculpture in New Jersey (Princeton, NJ: Van Nostrand, 1964), p. 56. {{Bonaparte family}} {{Bonaparte princesses by marriage}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bonaparte, Charlotte Napoleone}} [[Category:1802 births]] [[Category:1839 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths in childbirth]] [[Category:House of Bonaparte|Charlotte Napoleone Bonaparte]] [[Category:People from Bordentown, New Jersey]] [[Category:People from Hunterdon County, New Jersey]] [[Category:Princesses of France (Bonaparte)|Charlotte Napoleone Bonaparte]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox anatomy | Name = Cortical reaction | Latin = | Image = | Caption = | Image2 = Gray3.png | Caption2 = Human [[ovum]]. The [[zona pellucida]] is seen as a thick clear girdle surrounded by the cells of the [[Corona radiata (embryology)|Corona radiata]]. | System = }}
The '''cortical reaction''' is a process initiated during [[fertilisation|fertilization]] by the release of [[cortical granule]]s from the egg, which prevents [[polyspermy]], the fusion of multiple sperm with one egg. In contrast to the [[Polyspermy#Fast block of polyspermy|fast block of polyspermy]] which immediately but temporarily blocks additional sperm from fertilizing the egg, the cortical reaction gradually establishes a permanent barrier to sperm entry and functions as the main part of the [[Polyspermy#Slow block of polyspermy|slow block of polyspermy]] in many animals.
To create this barrier [[cortical granule]]s, specialized [[Vesicle (biology)#Secretory vesicles|secretory vesicles]] located within the egg's [[cell cortex|cortex]] (the region directly below the plasma membrane), are fused with the egg's plasma membrane, causing the contents of the cortical granules to be released outside the cell where they modify an existing extracellular matrix to make it impenetrable to sperm entry. The cortical granules contain [[proteases]] that clip perivitelline tether proteins, [[peroxidases]] that harden the vitelline envelope, and [[glycosaminoglycans]] that attract water into the perivitelline space, causing it to expand and form the [[hyaline layer]]. The trigger for the cortical granules to [[Exocytosis|exocytose]] is the release of calcium ions from cortical [[smooth endoplasmic reticulum]] in response to sperm binding to the egg.
In most animals, the extracellular matrix present around the egg is the [[Vitelline membrane|vitelline envelope]] which becomes the fertilization membrane following the cortical reaction. In mammals, however, the extracellular matrix modified by the cortical reaction is the [[zona pellucida]]. This modification of the zona pellucida is known as the zona reaction. Although highly conserved across the animal kingdom, the cortical reaction shows great diversity between species. While much has been learned about the identity and function of the contents of the cortical granules in the highly accessible sea urchin, little is known about the contents of cortical granules in mammals.
The cortical reaction within the egg is analogous to the [[acrosomal reaction]] within the sperm, where the acrosome, a specialized secretory vesicle that is homologous to cortical granules, is fused with the plasma membrane of the sperm cell to release its contents which degrade the egg's tough coating and allow the sperm to bind to and fuse with the egg.
==Echinoderms== In the well-studied [[sea urchin]] model system, the granule contents modify a protein coat on the outside of the plasma membrane (the vitelline layer) so that it is released from the membrane. The released cortical granule proteins exert a [[colloid]] [[osmotic pressure]] causing water to enter the space between the plasma membrane and the vitelline layer, and the vitelline layer expands away from the egg surface. This is easily visible through a microscope and is known as "elevation of the fertilization envelope". Some of the former granule contents adhere to the fertilization envelope, and it is extensively modified and cross-linked. As the fertilization envelope elevates, non-fertilizing sperm are lifted away from the egg plasma membrane, and as they are not able to pass through the fertilization envelope, they are prevented from entering the egg. Therefore, the cortical reaction prevents [[polyspermy|polyspermic]] fertilization, a lethal event. Another cortical granule component, polysaccharide-rich hyalin, remains adherent to the outer surface of the plasma membrane, and becomes part of the hyaline layer.
==Mammals== Although various mammals have been studied, mice represent the best studied animal models for understanding the cortical reaction in mammals. In mammals the cortical reaction leads to a modification of the [[zona pellucida]] that blocks polyspermy; enzymes released by cortical granules digest sperm receptor glycoproteins ZP2 and ZP3 so that they can no longer bind spermatozoon.
==See also== *[[Acrosome reaction]] - The analogous reaction in the acrosome of the sperm by Leomoraks
==References== *Haley SA, Wessel GM. Sea urchin cortical granules regulated proteolysis by cortical granule serine protease 1 at fertilisation. Mol Biol Cell. 2004 May;15(5):2084-92. *Sadler TW. Langman's Medical Embryology. Baltimore: Lippincott Williams and Wilkins, 2006.
==External links== * [http://www.molbiolcell.org/cgi/content/full/15/5/2084 Regulated Proteolysis by Cortical Granule Serine Protease 1 at Fertilization]
[[Category:Germ cells]] [[Category:Reproductive system]] [[Category:Developmental biology]]

{{multiple issues| {{POV|date=January 2017}} {{cite check|date=April 2017}} }}
<!-- Come to a consensus about the title before moving the page again. --> '''Day-care sex-abuse hysteria''' was a [[moral panic]] that occurred primarily in the 1980s and early 1990s featuring charges against [[day care|day-care]] providers of several forms of [[child abuse]], including [[Satanic ritual abuse]].<ref name=pbs/><ref>{{cite news|first=L |last=Miller |authorlink= |title=Parole Board recommends Amirault's commutation |url=http://www.truthinjustice.org/amirault.htm |quote=The Amiraults always insisted they were innocent, the victims of a sex-abuse hysteria that swept the country in the 1980s and questionable testimony from child witnesses. |agency=Associated Press |date=2001-07-06 |accessdate=2007-10-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071104063907/http://truthinjustice.org/amirault.htm |archivedate=2007-11-04 |df= }}</ref> A prominent case in [[Kern County, California]] first brought the issue of day-care sexual abuse to the forefront of the public awareness, and the issue figured prominently in news coverage for almost a decade. The Kern County case was followed by cases elsewhere in the United States as well as Canada, New Zealand, Brazil, and various European countries.
==Causes==
===Anxiety=== In the late 1970s and early 1980s, more and more mothers were working outside of the home, resulting in the opening of large numbers of day-care centers. Anxiety and guilt over leaving young children with strangers may have created a climate of fear and readiness to believe false accusations.<ref name=Peggy/><ref>{{cite book |last=Pendergrast |first=Mark |authorlink=Mark Pendergrast |title=Victims of Memory: Sex Abuse Accusations and Shattered Lives |publisher= |quote='It seems [the day-care sex- abuse hysteria] had something to do with this fear that we'd turned our kids over to total strangers,' sociologist Catherine Beckett says ... |isbn=978-0-942679-18-2|year=1996 }}</ref>
===Suggestions and false allegations when interviewing children=== {{synthesis|section|talksection=Synthesis in discussion of causes|date=November 2016}}
Children are vulnerable to outside influences that lead to fabrication of testimony.<ref>{{cite book |last=Carter |first=Sherrie Bourg |title=Children in the Courtroom |year=2005 |page=21}}</ref> Their testimony can be influenced in a variety of ways. Maggie Bruck in her article published by the [[American Psychological Association]] wrote that children incorporate aspects of the interviewer's questions into their answers in an attempt to tell the interviewer what the child believes is being sought.<ref name="ceci">{{harvnb|Ceci|Bruck|1996}}</ref> Studies also show that when adults ask children questions that do not make sense (such as "is milk bigger than water?" or "is red heavier than yellow?"), most children will offer an answer, believing that there is an answer to be given, rather than understand the absurdity of the question.<ref>{{cite book |last=McGough |first=Lucy S. |title=Child Witnesses: Fragile Voices in the American Legal System |year=1994 |page=72}}</ref> Furthermore, repeated questioning of children causes them to change their answers. This is because the children perceive the repeated questioning as a sign that they did not give the "correct" answer previously.<ref name = "Ceci79">{{harvnb|Ceci|Bruck|1996|pp=79–81}}</ref> Children are also especially susceptible to leading and [[suggestive question]]s.<ref>Carter, p. 21.</ref> Some studies have shown that only a small percentage of children produce fictitious reports of sexual abuse on their own.<ref>Jones, D. P. H., and J. M. McGraw: Reliable and Fictitious Accounts of Sexual Abuse to Children. Journal of Interpersonal Violence, 2, 27–45, 1987 {{doi|10.1177/088626087002001002}} [http://jiv.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/2/1/27]</ref><ref>Oates, R. K., D.P. Jones, D. Denson, A. Sirotnak, N. Gary, and R.D. Krugman: Erroneous Concerns about Child Sexual Abuse. Child Abuse & Neglect 24: 149–57, 2000 [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10660017] "There were 14 (2.5%) erroneous concerns emanating from children."</ref><ref>Everson, M.D., and B. W. Boat: False Allegations of Sexual Abuse by Children and Adolescents. Journal of the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, 28, 230–35, 1989.</ref><ref>{{Citation | quote=False allegations of sexual abuse by children and adolescents are statistically uncommon, occurring at the rate of 2 to 10 percent of all cases.|author=Mikkelsen, E.J.|author2=T.G. Gutheil|author3=M Emens|title=False Sexual-Abuse Allegations by Children and Adolescents: Contextual Factors and Clinical Subtypes|volume=46|issue=4|pages=556–70|periodical=American Journal of Psychotherapy 46: 556–70, 1992.|pmid=1443285|year=1992|doi=10.1176/appi.psychotherapy.1992.46.4.556}}</ref> Other studies have shown that children understate occurrences of abuse.<ref>{{Citation|last1=Lawson|first1=L.|last2=Chaffin|first2=M|title= False negatives in sexual abuse disclosure interviews|periodical=Journal of Interpersonal Violence, 7(4)|pages=532–42|year=1992}}</ref><ref name="Sjoberg">{{cite journal | last1=Sjoberg|first1=R. L.|last2=Lindblad|first2=F|title=Limited disclosure of sexual abuse in children whose experiences were documented by videotape|journal =American Journal of Psychiatry | volume = 159 | issue = 2 | pages = 312–14 | year=2002|url=http://ajp.psychiatryonline.org/cgi/content/full/159/2/312 | doi=10.1176/appi.ajp.159.2.312|pmid=11823279}}</ref><ref name="Malloy">{{cite journal |last1=Malloy|first1=L.C.|last2=Lyon|first2=T.D.|last3=Quas|first3=J.A.|year=2007|title=Filial dependency and recantation of child sexual abuse allegations|journal =Journal of the American Academy of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry | volume = 46|issue=2|pages=162–70|doi=10.1097/01.chi.0000246067.77953.f7|pmid=17242619}}</ref>
Interviewer bias also plays a role in shaping child testimony. When an interviewer has a preconceived notion as to the truth of the matter being investigated, the questioning is conducted in a manner to extract statements that support these beliefs.<ref name = "Ceci79"/> As a result, evidence that could disprove the belief is never sought by the interviewer. Additionally, positive reinforcement by the interviewer can taint child testimony. Often such reinforcement is given to encourage a spirit of cooperation by the child, but the impartial tone can quickly disappear as the interviewer nods, smiles, or offers verbal encouragement to "helpful" statements.<ref name = "Ceci79"/> Some studies show that when interviewers make reassuring statements to child witnesses, the children are more likely to fabricate stories of past events that never occurred.<ref name="ceci140">{{harvnb|Ceci|Bruck|1996|p=140}}</ref>
Peer pressure also influences children to fabricate stories. Studies show that when a child witness is told that his or her friends have already testified that certain events occurred, the child witness was more likely to create a matching story.<ref>{{harvnb|Ceci|Bruck|1996|pp=146–47}}</ref> The status of the interviewer can also influence a child's testimony, because the more authority an interviewer has such as a police officer, the more likely a child is to comply with that person's agenda.<ref>{{harvnb|Ceci|Bruck|1996|p=152}}</ref>
Finally, while there are supporters of the use of [[anatomically correct doll]]s in questioning victims of sexual abuse/molestation, there are also critics of this practice.<ref name ="Ceci162">{{harvnb|Ceci|Bruck|1996|p=162}}</ref> These critics say that because of the novelty of the dolls, children will act out sexually explicit acts with the dolls even if the child has not been sexually abused.<ref name ="Ceci162"/> Another criticism is that because the studies that compare the differences between how abused and non-abused children play with these dolls are conflicting (some studies suggest that sexually abused children play with anatomically correct dolls in a more sexually explicit manner than non-abused children, while other studies suggest that there is no correlation), it is impossible to interpret what is meant by how a child plays with these dolls.<ref name ="Ceci162"/>
==Timeline== * 1982 – Kern county child abuse case * 1983 – McMartin preschool trial in California * 1984 – Fells Acres Day Care Center * 1984 – Bernard F. Baran, Jr., convicted January 30, 1985. * 1985 – Bronx Five case * 1985 – Wee Care Nursery School in [[New Jersey]] in April * 1987 – [[Cleveland child abuse scandal]] in [[England]] * 1987 – Friedman cases begin * 1989 – Glendale Montessori sexual abuse case in Stuart, Florida * 1989 – Little Rascals Day Care Center scandal in Edenton, North Carolina * 1990 – All charges dropped in McMartin preschool trial * 1991 – Dan and Fran Keller, Fran's Daycare Center, Oak Hill, Texas * 1991 – Christchurch Civic Creche, New Zealand, involving [[Peter Hugh McGregor Ellis]] * 1992 – Kaare Sortland is killed after being found not guilty of child abuse * 1992 – Martensville Scandal, Martensville, Saskatchewan, Canada * 1994 – Wenatchee Sex Rings case * 1996 – Convictions in the Kern county child abuse case overturned * 2013 – Dan and Fran Keller released from prison, four years before being ruled innocent of the charges against them
==Significant cases==
===McMartin Preschool=== {{Main|McMartin preschool trial}}
The McMartin Preschool case was the first daycare abuse case to receive major media attention in the United States.<ref name="CAV"/> The case centered upon the McMartin Preschool in [[Manhattan Beach, California]], where seven teachers were accused of kidnapping children, flying them in a plane to another location, and forcing them to engage in group sex as well as forcing them to watch [[Cruelty to animals|animals be tortured and killed]].<ref name="CAV"/> The case also involved accusations that children had been forced to participate in bizarre religious rituals, and been used to make child pornography.<ref name="Jenkins"/> The case began with a single accusation, made by the mother - who was later found to be a paranoid schizophrenic<ref name=Peggy>{{cite news |first=Margaret |last=Talbot |authorlink= |title=The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: Peggy McMartin Buckey, b. 1926; The Devil in The Nursery. |url=http://www.newamerica.net/publications/articles/2001/the_devil_in_the_nursery |format=reprint from New America |quote=Buckey's ordeal began in 1983, when the mother of a 2½-year-old who attended the McMartin preschool in [[Manhattan Beach, California|Manhattan Beach]], [[California]], called the police to report that her son had been sodomized there. It didn't matter that the woman was eventually found to be a paranoid schizophrenic, and that the accusations she made – of teachers who took children on airplane rides to Palm Springs and lured them into a labyrinth of underground tunnels where the accused "flew in the air" and others were "all dressed up as witches" ... |publisher=The New York Times |date=January 7, 2001 |accessdate=2007-07-21}}</ref> - of one of the students, but grew rapidly when investigators informed parents of the accusation and began interviewing other students.<ref name="Jenkins"/> The case made headlines nationwide in 1984, and seven teachers were arrested and charged that year.<ref name="Jenkins"/> When a new district attorney took over the case in 1986, however, his office re-examined the evidence and dropped charges against all but two of the original defendants. Their trials became one of the longest and most expensive criminal trials in the history of the United States,<ref name="Jenkins"/><ref name=pbs/> but in 1990 all of these charges were also dropped.<ref name="CAV"/> Both jurors at the trial and academic researchers later criticized the interviewing techniques that investigators had used in their investigations of the school, alleging that interviewers had "coaxed" children into making unfounded accusations, repeatedly asking children the same questions and offering various incentives until the children reported having been abused.<ref name="CAV"/> Most scholars now agree that the accusations these interviews elicited from children were false.<ref name="Schreiber"/><ref name="Garven"/> Sociologist [[Mary de Young]] and historian [[Philip Jenkins]] have both cited the McMartin case as the prototype for a wave of similar accusations and investigations between 1983 and 1995, which constituted a moral panic.<ref name="de Young"/><ref name="Jenkins"/>
===Country Walk=== In 1985, Frank Fuster – the owner of the Country Walk Babysitting Service in the [[Country Walk, Florida|Country Walk]] suburb of [[Miami|Miami, Florida]] – was found guilty of 14 counts of abuse.<ref name=Collins/> He was sentenced to prison with a minimum length of 165 years. Fuster's alleged victims testified that he led them in Satanic rituals and terrorized them by forcing them to watch him mutilate birds, a lesson to children who might reveal the abuse.<ref name=Collins>{{cite news |last=Collins |first=Glen |title=Nightmare in Country Walk |publisher=The New York Times |date=1986-12-14 |quote=Mr. Fuster was convicted of molesting the children entrusted to his wife's care in their home in the middle-class Dade County suburb of Country Walk, a planned development that was intended to be an idyllic refuge from the anxieties of urban Miami. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/12/14/books/nightmare-in-country-walk.html?pagewanted=print |accessdate=2008-07-01}}</ref> Fuster had been previously convicted for manslaughter and for molesting a 9-year-old child.<ref name=pbs/> Testimony from children in the case was elicited by [[University of Miami]] [[child psychologist]]s Laurie and Joseph Braga, who resorted to coercive questioning of the alleged victims when the desired answers were not forthcoming.<ref>{{cite book |author=De Young, Mary |authorlink=Mary de Young |title=The day care ritual abuse moral panic |publisher=McFarland |location=Jefferson, N.C |year=2004 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=_e8ZkJBtz0EC&pg=PA71#v=onepage&q&f=false 71] |isbn=978-0-7864-1830-5 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> Fuster's wife recanted her court testimony in an interview with Frontline, saying that she had been kept naked in solitary confinement and subjected to other forms of physical and psychological duress until she had agreed to testify against her husband.<ref>{{cite episode|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/fuster/etc/video.html|title=Did Daddy Do It|publisher=PBS|transcript=Transcript|transcript-url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/fuster/etc/script.html|date=April 25, 2002|series=Frontline}}</ref>
The case was prosecuted by Dade County state's attorney [[Janet Reno]].<ref name=pbs2>{{cite web |title=Was Fuster a Monster?: A Summary of the Frank Fuster "Country Walk" Case |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/fuster/frank/summary.html |work=Frontline |accessdate=10 March 2014}}</ref> As of June 2017, Fuster continues to serve a 165-year prison sentence.<ref name=pbs2 /><ref name=flyer>{{cite web |title=Florida Department of Law Enforcement – Sexual Offender / Predator Flyer |url=http://offender.fdle.state.fl.us/offender/flyer.do?personId=58857 |accessdate=10 March 2014}}</ref> The incident also inspired a book and made-for-TV movie called ''Unspeakable Acts'' (1990).
===Fells Acres Day Care Center=== {{Main|Fells Acres Day Care Center preschool trial}}
In April 1984, [[Gerald Amirault]] was arrested and charged with abusing children in his care at the Fells Acres Day Care Center in [[Malden, Massachusetts]].<ref name="Beck2015">{{cite book|author=Richard Beck|title=We Believe the Children: A Moral Panic in the 1980s|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x99-BAAAQBAJ|date=4 August 2015|publisher=PublicAffairs|isbn=978-1-61039-288-4}}</ref><ref name="Nation">{{cite magazine |url=https://www.thenation.com/article/finality-or-justice/ |title='Finality' or Justice? |first=Katha |last=Pollitt |date=18 September 1999 |magazine=The Nation}}</ref> After Gerald changed the pants on a young boy who had wet himself, the boy's mother, uncle and therapist questioned him over a period of months, until the boy alleged that Gerald had been sexually abusing him. The boy's mother then called a child abuse hotline to report that her son had been sexually abused, and Gerald was arrested shortly thereafter.<ref name="Rabinowitz2004"/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/30/us/day-care-workers-get-retrial-as-accusers-did-not-face-them.html |url-access=subscription |title=Day Care Workers Get Retrial, As Accusers Did Not Face Them |agency=The Associated Press |newspaper=The New York Times |date=30 August 1995}}</ref><ref name="Nation"/> In the 1986 trial, Gerald was convicted of assaulting and raping nine children and sentenced to thirty to forty years in state prison. In a separate trial, his mother, Violet Amirault, and sister, Cheryl Amirault LeFave, were also convicted of similar charges and sentenced to jail for eight to 20 years.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Day Care Workers Get Retrial, As Accusers Did Not Face Them. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/30/us/day-care-workers-get-retrial-as-accusers-did-not-face-them.html |publisher=The New York Times |date=August 30, 1995 |accessdate=2008-03-23}}</ref> According to Richard Beck, the case developed "in the usual way" compared to other moral panic cases, with more and more children leveling increasingly bizarre allegations against the accused during the course of the investigation.<ref name="Beck2015"/> The allegations included reports of "bad clowns," robots, "magic rooms," and tortured animals.<ref name="ATC">"Profile: Case of Gerald Amirault, a convicted child sex offender, and the prosecution of child sexual molestation cases." All Things Considered, April 19, 2000. General OneFile (accessed May 3, 2017).</ref> According to Beck, one of the prosecutors responsible for the case commented that coaxing allegations out of the children had been like "getting blood from a stone."<ref name="Beck2015"/>
In 1995, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' journalist [[Dorothy Rabinowitz]] questioned testimony from the children that had been elicited with dubious interrogation techniques, writing, "no sane person reading the transcripts of these interrogations can doubt the wholesale fabrications of evidence on which this case was built."<ref name=darkness>{{cite news |first=Dorothy |last=Rabinowitz |authorlink=Dorothy Rabinowitz |title=A Darkness in Massachusetts |url=http://www.opinionjournal.com/extra/?id=95000779|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090303131406/http://www.opinionjournal.com/extra/?id=95000779|archive-date=March 3, 2009 |quote=On Labor Day 1984, 60-year-old Violet Amirault, proprietor of the thriving Fells Acres Day School in [[Malden, Massachusetts|Malden]], [[Massachusetts]], received a call about a child-abuse accusation against her son. Two days later the police arrested 31-year-old Gerald (who worked at Fells Acres) on charges of raping a five-year-old boy, a new pupil. |date=January 30, 1995 |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]}}</ref><ref name=darknessII>{{cite news |first=Dorothy |last=Rabinowitz |authorlink=Dorothy Rabinowitz |title=A Darkness in Massachusetts – II |url=http://opinionjournal.com/extra/?id=95000780|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090303131427/http://opinionjournal.com/extra/?id=95000780|archive-date=March 3, 2009|quote=A few months after Violet and Cheryl Amirault were imprisoned for committing, the State alleged, barbarous sexual assaults on small children, the prosecutors sponsored a seminar titled "The Fells Acres Day School Case – A Model Multidisciplinary Response." |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=March 14, 1995}}</ref> Rabinowitz was a finalist for the 1996 Pulitzer Prize for her newspaper columns on the issue,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pulitzer.org/winners/dorothy-rabinowitz |title=Dorothy Rabinowitz of The Wall Street Journal |website=The Pulitzer Prises}}</ref> and made the Amirault's case a centerpiece of her book ''No Crueler Tyrannies: Accusation, False Witness, and Other Terrors of Our Times.''<ref name="Rabinowitz2004">{{cite book|author=Dorothy Rabinowitz|title=No Crueler Tyrannies: Accusation, False Witness, and Other Terrors of Our Times|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QfH4E_WHBzIC|date=2 March 2004|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-0-7432-2840-4}}</ref> Violet and Cheryl were granted a new trial in 1997, on the basis that they had been denied the right to face their accusers and had been inadequately represented at trial, but Violet died and a judge reduced Cheryl's sentence to time served before the new trial could proceed.<ref>Kathleen Burge, "Board Grants Parole to Amirault," ''Boston Globe'' 18 October 2003.</ref> In 2001, the Massachusetts Board of Pardons recommended that Gerald's sentence be commuted, citing "substantial doubt" about his guilt. He was granted parole in 2003.<ref>"Freedom for Gerald Amirault," ''Hartford Courant,'' 23 October 2003</ref> Writing about the case at the time of Gerald's release, ''The Economist'' suggested in an editorial that while the Amiraults had long maintained their innocence and had attracted a "string of prominent supporters" who believed that they had been wrongly convicted, "many others continue to believe that Mr. Amirault committed the crimes."<ref>"A matter of evidence; crime and punishment," ''The Economist.'' 1 May 2004.</ref>
===Bernard Baran===
{{Main|Bernard Baran}}
On October 4, 1984, a drug addicted couple acting as police informants<ref>{{cite news |title=Video helps clear convict of abuse after 21 years. |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/32341725/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/ |agency=The Associated Press |work=MSNBC |date=2009-08-09 |quote=The first complaint came from a drug addicted couple.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Berman |first=D. |last2=Lock |first2=C. |last3=Rainey |first3=R. |last4=Taub |first4=L. |date=2004-06-24 |url=http://www.bostonphoenix.com/boston/news_features/top/features/documents/03917095.asp |title=The Trials of Bernard Baran |newspaper=[[Boston Phoenix|The Boston Phoenix]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612171804/http://bostonphoenix.com/boston/news_features/top/features/documents/03917095.asp |archive-date=2010-06-12 |quote='It was a way of life,' Joe Hill acknowledged in court documents, 'Nembutal, Seconal, Percodan, Heroin, cocaine, Methedrine. Is that enough?'}}</ref> called their contact in the Pittsfield, Massachusetts, police department to accuse Bernard Baran of molesting their son. The child had been attending the government operated Early Childhood Development Center (ECDC) where Baran, an openly gay 19-year-old, worked as a teacher's aide. The accusers had previously complained to the board of directors that they "didn't want no homo" around their son.<ref>Superior Court Criminal Action No. 18042-51. The Commonwealth of Massachusetts versus Bernard F. Baran, Jr. Memorandum of Decision and Order on Defendant's Motion For A New Trial. 2006-06-21. Background, p. 6. "In 1984, Bernard Baran worked at the Early Childhood Development Center ('ECDC') as a teacher's aide. The allegations in this case emanate from his contact with pre-school children who were enrolled in this facility. The first family to bring accusations against Mr. Baran was that of Boy A. Previously, the boy's father had filed a complaint with ECDC objecting to Mr. Baran being allowed to work with children because he was a homosexual. On September 12th, 1984, the ECDC Board of Directors discussed Mr. Baran's sexuality and his possible termination. On October 5th, 1984, this family contacted the police to report that Mr. Baran had molested their child."</ref><ref>"Video helps clear convict of abuse after 21 years." http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/32341725/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/ Associated Press / MSNBC. 2009-08-09. His case had followed a tortured path – the first complaint came from a drug-addicted couple, acting as narcotics informants, who told their police connection they "didn't want no homo" watching their son.</ref>
Within days of the first allegation, ECDC hosted a puppet show and delivered letters to parents notifying them about a child at the day care with [[gonorrhea]]. Five other allegations emerged. Baran was tried in the Berkshire County courthouse 105 days after the first allegation, a swiftness noted in the later court rulings. The courtroom was closed during the children's testimony, which Baran claimed violated his right to a public trial. Baran's defense attorney was later ruled ineffective. Baran was convicted on January 30, 1985, on three counts of rape of a child and five counts of indecent assault and battery. He was sentenced to three life terms plus 8 to 20 years on each charge. He maintained his innocence throughout his case.<ref>Pollitt, Katha. 2000-02-03. [http://www.thenation.com/article/justice-bernard-baran "Justice for Bernard Baran."] [[The Nation]] "Baran maintained his innocence throughout his imprisonment, making him ineligible for parole."</ref> In 1999 a new legal team took up his case. In 2004 hearings began in a motion for a new trial. In 2006, Baran was granted a new trial and released on $50,000 bail. In May 2009, the Massachusetts Appeals Court affirmed the new trial ruling, setting aside the 1985 convictions. The Berkshire County District Attorney's office dismissed the original charges and Baran's record was cleared.<ref>"D.A. Capeless decides not to continue prosecuting Baran." 2009-06-09. [http://www.mass.gov/?pageID=berpressrelease&L=1&L0=Home&sid=Dber&b=pressrelease&f=20090609_baran_bernard&csid=Dber The Berkshire County District Attorney's Office]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100808111332/http://www.mass.gov/?pageID=berpressrelease&L=1&L0=Home&sid=Dber&b=pressrelease&f=20090609_baran_bernard&csid=Dber |date=2010-08-08 }}</ref>{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
===The Bronx Five=== Prosecutor [[Mario Merola (lawyer)|Mario Merola]] brought prosecutions leading to the conviction of five men, including Nathaniel Grady, a 47-year-old Methodist minister, of sexually abusing children in day care centers throughout [[the Bronx]].<ref name=pbs/><ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=20th-century witch hunt. |url= |quote=The Rev. Nathaniel Grady, a pious man and a fiery orator, was born to do the Lord's work. As a boy, he walked to Sunday school hand-in-hand with his mother and sister. As an adult, he became a Methodist minister, shepherding a devoted flock in the rugged East Bronx while fostering friendships with judges, bishops, police chiefs, an ex-governor. Yet, prosecutors ignored Nat Grady's past when he was accused in 1984 of sexually abusing a half-dozen ... |agency=Associated Press |date=December 1, 1996 |accessdate=}}</ref> Grady spent ten years in prison before being released in 1996.
Three employees of another Bronx day-care center were arrested in August 1984 on the charges of abusing at least ten children in their care.<ref>{{cite news |last=Berger |first=J. |title=3 Seized in Child Abuse at Bronx Center |page=1 |language= |publisher=The New York Times |date=August 3, 1984 |url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0710F63D5C0C708CDDA10894DC484D81 |accessdate=2008-03-23}}</ref> Federal and city investigators then questioned dozens of children at the day care. They used 'dolls, gentle words and a quiet approach.'<ref>{{cite news |last=McFadden |first=R. |title=Search For Witnesses Widens In Inquiry On Day-Care Center |language= |publisher=The New York Times |date=August 5, 1984 |url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0710FC3C5C0C768CDDA10894DC484D81 |accessdate=2008-03-23}}</ref> More children reported being sexually abused, raising the total to 30.<ref>{{cite news |last=Purdum |first=T. |title=18 More Children Cite Sexual Abuse |language= |publisher=The New York Times |date=August 7, 1984 |url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70E1FF83C5C0C748CDDA10894DC484D81 |accessdate=2008-03-23}}</ref> Three more day care centers also were investigated for sexual abuse.<ref>{{cite news |last=Purdum |first=T. |title=Sexual Abuse Is Investigated At 3 More Day-Care Centers |language= |publisher=The New York Times |date=August 9, 1984 |url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50913FF3F5C0C7A8CDDA10894DC484D81 |accessdate=2008-03-23}}</ref> On August 11, 1984, federal funds were cut off to the Head Start preschool program at the Praca Day Care Center and three employees had been arrested.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997-01-05/news/mn-15543_1_day-care-center |title=For Wrongly Accused Day-Care Workers, Freedom Is No Panacea |first=Larry |last=McShane |date=5 January 1997 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |agency=The Associated Press}}</ref> In June 1985, the day care center was reopened with new sponsorship.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/06/01/nyregion/child-care-center-reopens-burying-the-tales-of-abuse.html?mcubz=1 |title=Child-care Center Reopens, Burying the Tales of Abuse |first=Carlyle C. |last=Douglas |newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref>
In January 1986, Albert Algerin, employed at the Praca Day Care center, was sentenced to 50 years for rape and sexual abuse.<ref>{{cite news |title=Day Care Worker Gets 50 Years for Sex Crimes |agency=Associated Press |publisher=The New York Times |date=January 16, 1986 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/01/16/nyregion/day-care-worker-gets-50-years-for-sex-crimes.html |accessdate=2008-03-23}}</ref> In May, Praca employee Jesus Torres, a former teacher's aide was sentenced to 40 years.<ref>{{cite news |title=Day-Care Sex Assaults Bring 30-Year Sentence. |language= |publisher=The New York Times |date=May 2, 1986 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/05/02/nyregion/day-care-sex-assaults-bring-30-year-sentence.html |accessdate=2008-03-23}}</ref> Praca employee Franklin Beauchamp had his case overturned in [[New York Court of Appeals]] in May 1989.<ref>{{cite news |title=Prosecutor Won't Seek New Abuse Charges |agency=Associated Press |language= |publisher=The New York Times |date=September 21, 1989 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/21/nyregion/prosecutor-won-t-seek-new-abuse-charges.html |accessdate=2008-03-23}}</ref>
All five convictions were ultimately overturned.<ref name=pbs/>
===Wee Care Nursery School=== {{Main|Wee Care Nursery School}} {{over-quotation|section|date=April 2017}} In [[Maplewood, New Jersey|Maplewood]], [[New Jersey]], in April 1985,<ref name=pbs/> Margaret Kelly Michaels was indicted for 299 offenses in connection with the sexual assault of 33 children.<ref>{{cite news |title=Day-Care Worker Held In Assaults On Children |language= |publisher=The New York Times |date=December 8, 1985 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/12/08/nyregion/day-care-worker-held-in-assaults-on-children.html |accessdate=2008-03-23 |quote=An employee of a day-care center in Maplewood, N.J., has been indicted for 229 offenses in connection with the sexual assault of 33 children between 3 and 6 years of age over a 6-month period.}}</ref> Michaels denied the charges.<ref name=Narvaez>{{cite news |last=Narvaez |first=A. |title=Former Day-Care Teacher Denies Sexually Abusing Schoolchildren |language= |publisher=The New York Times |date=February 28, 1988 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/02/28/nyregion/former-day-care-teacher-denies-sexually-abusing-schoolchildren.html |accessdate=2008-03-23 |quote=A former day-care center teacher being tried on charges of sexually abusing 20 children in her care testified in her defense this week and denied ever having had sexual contact with the 3- 4- and 5-year-old youngsters.}}</ref> "The prosecution produced expert witnesses who said that almost all the children displayed symptoms of sexual abuse."<ref name=Narvaez2>{{cite news |last=Narvaez |first=A. |title=Legal Arguments End in Jersey Child-Abuse Trial |language= |publisher=The New York Times |date=March 29, 1988 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/03/29/nyregion/legal-arguments-end-in-jersey-child-abuse-trial.html?pagewanted=2 |accessdate=2008-03-23 |quote=Legal arguments in the nine-month trial of a day-care teacher accused of sexually abusing 20 children at a center in Maplewood ended here today.}}</ref> Prosecution witnesses testified that the children "had regressed into such behavior as bed-wetting and defecating in their clothing. The witnesses said the children became afraid to be left alone or to stay in the dark."<ref name=Narvaez2/> Some of the other teachers testified against her.<ref name=Narvaez2/> "The defense argued that Michaels did not have the time or opportunity to go to a location where all the activities could have taken place without someone seeing her."<ref name=Narvaez2/>
Michaels was sentenced to 47 years in the "sex case."<ref name=Rangel>{{cite news |last=Rangel |first=J. |title=Ex-Preschool Teacher Sentenced To 47 Years in Sex Case in Jersey |language= |publisher=The New York Times |date=August 3, 1988 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/08/03/nyregion/ex-preschool-teacher-sentenced-to-47-years-in-sex-case-in-jersey.html |accessdate=2008-03-23 |quote=A former preschool teacher was sentenced today to 47 years in prison for sexually assaulting 19 children and endangering the welfare of another child in a day-care center in Maplewood}}</ref> Michaels "told the judge that she was confident her conviction would be overturned on appeal."<ref name=Rangel/> After five years in prison her appeal was successful and sentence was overturned by a New Jersey appeals court. The [[New Jersey Supreme Court]] upheld the appellate court's decision and declared "the interviews of the children were highly improper and utilized coercive and unduly suggestive methods."<ref>{{cite news |first=Susan |last=Chira |authorlink= |title=Recovered Reputations. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/06/books/recovered-reputations.html |publisher=The New York Times |date=April 6, 2003 | <!--quote=There are few accusations more horrifying than that of sexually abusing a child. But Dorothy Rabinowitz, in her powerful, prosecutorial book, ''No Crueler Tyrannies,'' suggests an even more disturbing prospect: that this country was recently engulfed by a wave of hysteria that wrongly tarred innocent people with that terrible crime. The cases, thanks in part to Rabinowitz's reporting for ''[[Harper's Magazine]]'' and later ''The Wall Street Journal'', are by now infamous.--> |accessdate=2007-09-25}}</ref> A three judge panel ruled she had been denied a fair trial, because "the prosecution of the case had relied on testimony that should have been excluded because it improperly used an expert's theory, called the [[child sexual abuse accommodation syndrome]], to establish guilt."<ref name=Faison>{{cite news |last=Fiason |first=F. |title=Child-Abuse Conviction Of Woman Is Overturned |language= |publisher=The New York Times |date=March 27, 1993 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/03/27/nyregion/child-abuse-conviction-of-woman-is-overturned.html |accessdate=2008-03-23 |quote=A New Jersey appeals court yesterday overturned the conviction of Margaret Kelly Michaels, who was accused of sexually abusing 19 children at a day-care center in Maplewood, and who was sentenced to 47 years in prison after a celebrated trial in 1988.}}</ref> The original judge was also criticized "for the way in which he allowed the children to give televised testimony from his chambers."<ref name=Faison/>
===Glendale Montessori===
James Toward and Brenda Williams were accused of [[kidnapping]] and sexually abusing six boys who attended Glendale Montessori in [[Stuart, Florida]], as preschoolers in 1986 and 1987. Investigators claimed to know up to 60 victims, mostly from the ages 2 to 5.<ref name=Taylor>{{cite news |title=Headmaster's evil lives on in 20-year-old abuse case |publisher=PalmBeachPost.com |date=2008-03-01 |author=Jill Taylor}}</ref>
In 1988, Williams, an office manager, was convicted and sentenced to 10 years in prison. She pleaded no contest to sex and attempted kidnapping charges involving five boys and she was released from prison in 1993 after serving five years. In 1989, Toward, owner of Glendale [[Montessori]] School, pleaded guilty to [[child sexual abuse]] charges and received a 27-year sentence. While technically maintaining his innocence, he allowed a guilty plea to be entered against him, convicting him of molesting or kidnapping six boys. Toward was placed in [[involuntary commitment]] due to the [[Murder of Jimmy Ryce|Jimmy Ryce Act]]. Although he maintained his innocence, Toward said he plea-bargained to avoid an almost certain life sentence.<ref name=Taylor/>
===Little Rascals=== {{Main|Little Rascals day care sexual abuse trial}}
In [[Edenton, North Carolina]], in January 1989, a parent accused Bob Kelly of sexual abuse. Over the next several months, investigations and therapy led to allegations against dozens of other adults in the town, culminating in the arrest of seven adults.<ref>{{cite news |last=Smothers |first=R. |title=Child-Abuse Case Is Ordeal for a Town |language= |publisher=The New York Times |date=August 19, 1991 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/19/us/child-abuse-case-is-ordeal-for-a-town.html |accessdate=2008-03-23}}</ref>
Despite the severity of some of the alleged acts, parents noticed no abnormal behaviour in their children until after initial accusations were made.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Bob Kelly's trial lasted eight months and on April 22, 1992, he was convicted of 99 out of 100 counts against him.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} In 1995, the [[North Carolina Court of Appeals]] granted new trials to two defendants, including Kelly.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Charges were ultimately dropped for both.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997-05-24/news/mn-62136_1_day-care-center|title=Day-Care Molestation Case Dropped|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=May 24, 1997|agency=[[The Associated Press]]}}</ref>
The remainder of the defendants received a variety of sentences.<ref name = JITC>{{harvnb|Ceci|Bruck|1996|pp=9–11}}</ref>
===Dale Akiki=== {{Main|Faith Chapel Church ritual abuse case}}
Dale Akiki, a developmentally-delayed man with [[Noonan syndrome]], was accused of satanic ritual abuse in 1991. Akiki and his wife were volunteer babysitters at Faith Chapel in [[Spring Valley, San Diego County, California|Spring Valley, California]]. The accusations started when a young girl told her mother that "[Akiki] showed me his penis," after which the mother contacted the police. After interviews, nine other children accused Akiki of killing animals, such as a giraffe and an elephant, and drinking their blood in front of the children. He was found not guilty of the 35 counts of child abuse and kidnapping in his 1993 trial.<ref name=pbs>{{cite web |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Innocence Lost, The Plea. |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/innocence/etc/other.html |publisher=[[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]] |accessdate=2009-03-20 }}</ref>
In 1994, the San Diego County Grand Jury reviewed the Akiki cases and concluded there was no reason to pursue the theory of ritual abuse.<ref>{{harvnb|Ceci|Bruck|1996|p=28}}</ref> On August 25, 1994, he filed a suit against the County of San Diego, Faith Chapel Church, and many others, which was settled for $2 million.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Akiki's [[public defender]]s received the Public Defender of the Year award for their work defending Akiki.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}}
===Oak Hill satanic ritual abuse trial=== {{Main|Oak Hill satanic ritual abuse trial}} Frances Keller and her husband, Dan Keller, both of [[Austin, Texas]], were convicted of sexually abusing a 3-year-old girl in their care, and they spent 21 years in prison until their release in 2013.<ref name="reuters">{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-texas-release-idUSBRE9AQ13R20131127|title=Texas frees daycare operator accused of 'satanic' sexual abuse|date=27 November 2013|publisher=|via=Reuters|newspaper=Reuters}}</ref>
The case began on August 15, 1991, when a 3-year-old girl told her mother that Dan Keller had hurt her. The mother and daughter were on their way to a scheduled appointment with the girl’s therapist, who drew out details that included Keller defecating on her head and sexually assaulting her with a pen. During the time leading up to the trial, two other children from the day care offered similar accusations. According to the children, the couple served blood-laced Kool-Aid and forced them to have videotaped sex with adults and other children. The Kellers, they said, sometimes wore white robes and lit candles before hurting them. The children also accused the Kellers of forcing them to watch or participate in the killing and dismemberment of cats, dogs and a crying baby. Bodies were unearthed in cemeteries and new holes dug to hide freshly killed animals and, once, an adult passer-by was shot and dismembered with a chain saw. The children recalled several plane trips, including one to [[Mexico]], where they were sexually abused by soldiers before returning to [[Austin]] in time to meet their parents at the day care.<ref name="case">{{cite web|url=http://www.statesman.com/news/news/local/fran-keller-to-be-freed-in-satanic-abuse-case/nb5S2/|title=Fran Keller to be freed in satanic abuse case|work=statesman.com}}</ref>
The only physical evidence of abuse in the case was presented by Michael Mouw, an emergency room physician at Brackenridge Hospital who examined the 3-year-old girl in 1991 on the night she first accused Dan Keller of abuse. Mouw testified at the Kellers’ trial that he found two tears in the girl’s hymen consistent with sexual abuse and determined that the injuries were less than 24 hours old. Three years after the trial, while attending a medical seminar, Mouw said a slide presentation on “normal” pediatric hymens included a photo that was identical to what he had observed in the girl.<ref name="case" /><ref>[http://www.kvue.com/news/editors-pick/233691871.html Austin attorneys weigh in on why Kellers were convicted] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131205081850/http://www.kvue.com/news/editors-pick/233691871.html |date=2013-12-05 }}</ref>
On November 26, 2013, the [[Travis County]] district attorney's office announced that Fran Keller, now 63, was being released on bond and her husband, Dan Keller, who was convicted at the same time, would be released within a week in a deal reached with lawyers. "There is a reasonable likelihood that (the medical expert's) false testimony affected the judgment of the jury and violated Frances Keller's right to a fair trial," said the district attorney.<ref name="reuters" />
On June 20, 2017, the Travis County district attorney's office announced that the case against the Kellers had been dismissed, citing actual innocence. They were awarded $3.4 million in compensation from the state of Texas for the 21 years they spent in prison.<ref name="exonerated">{{cite web|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/daily/news/2017-06-20/kellers-exonerated|title=Kellers Exonerated|publisher=Austin Chronicle}} {{cite web |url=http://www.mystatesman.com/news/crime--law/dan-fran-keller-get-million-satanic-day-care-case/dsYUsfqzNfvApC472mBPnK/|title=Kellers awarded $3.4M|publisher=Austin American-Statesman}}</ref>
===Wenatchee child abuse prosecutions=== {{Main|Wenatchee child abuse prosecutions}} In [[Wenatchee, Washington]], in 1994 and 1995, police and state social workers undertook what was then called the nation's most extensive child sex-abuse investigation.<ref name=pbs/> Forty-three adults were arrested on 29,726 charges of child sex abuse involving 60 children. Parents, Sunday school teachers and a pastor were charged, and many were convicted of abusing their own children or the children of others in the community. However, prosecutors were unable to provide any physical evidence to support the charges. The main witness was the 13-year-old foster daughter of police officer Robert Perez, who had investigated the cases.<ref>{{cite news |first=Timothy |last=Egan |authorlink= |title=Pastor and Wife Are Acquitted on All Charges in Sex-Abuse Case. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/12/us/pastor-and-wife-are-acquitted-on-all-charges-in-sex-abuse-case.html |publisher=The New York Times |date=1995-12-12 |accessdate=2007-07-21}}</ref> A jury found the city of Wenatchee and [[Douglas County, Washington]], negligent in the 1994–1995 investigations. In 2001, $3 million was awarded to a couple who had been wrongly accused in the inquiry.<ref name=doug>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Jury finds city, county negligent in child sex ring case. |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/local/33472_wenatchee01.shtml |quote=A Spokane County jury yesterday found the city of Wenatchee and Douglas County negligent in the now-discredited 1994–1995 Wenatchee child sex ring investigations, awarding $3 million to a couple who had been wrongly accused in the inquiry. |publisher=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] |date=2001-08-01 |accessdate=2007-11-26 |first1=Mike |last1=Barber |first2=Larry |last2=Lange}}</ref>
===Christchurch Civic Crèche=== {{Main|Peter Ellis (childcare worker)}} [[Peter Ellis (childcare worker)|Peter Ellis]], a child-care worker at the [[Christchurch]] Civic [[Day care|Crèche]] in [[New Zealand]], was found guilty on 16 counts of sexual abuse against children in 1992 and served seven years in jail. Parents of the alleged abuse victims were entitled to claim NZ$10,000 (equivalent to about US$11,000 in 2010) in compensation for each allegation from the [[Accident Compensation Corporation]], regardless of whether the allegations were proved or not. Many victims' families made multiple allegations. Four female co-workers were also arrested on 15 charges of abuse, but were released after these charges were dropped. Together with six other co-workers who lost their jobs when the centre was closed, they were awarded $1 million in compensation by the Employment Court in 1995, although this sum was reduced on appeal. Peter Ellis has consistently denied any abuse, and the case is still considered controversial by many New Zealanders.<ref name="Power">{{cite news|title=Government to reconsider Peter Ellis case |publisher=The Press |date=15 December 2008 |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/thepress/4793550a6009.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130113102452/http://www.stuff.co.nz/thepress/4793550a6009.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=13 January 2013 |accessdate=2009-01-25 }}</ref>
===Martensville satanic sex scandal=== {{Main|Martensville satanic sex scandal}} In 1992, a mother in the central [[Saskatchewan]] city of [[Martensville]], alleged that a local woman who ran a babysitting service and day care center in her home had sexually abused her child. Police began an investigation, leading to a sharp increase in allegations. More than a dozen persons, including five police officers from two different forces, ultimately faced over 100 charges connected with running a Satanic cult called The Brotherhood of The Ram, which allegedly practiced ritualized sexual abuse of numerous children at a "Devil Church".<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Satanic Sex Scandal |url=http://www.cbc.ca/fifth/martin/scandal.html |quote=The nightmare that descended on Martensville, Saskatchewan began when a local mother had some grave suspicions. She worked as a nurse at a Saskatoon hospital and left her kids with a babysitter only a few blocks from her home. ... By the spring of 1992 Martensville was reeling with rumours about a Satanic cult called The Brotherhood of The Ram that had police officers as members. It was an explosive situation and the Martensville police were under tremendous pressure to do something about it. |publisher=[[CBC News]] |date=February 12, 2003 |accessdate=2007-10-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103035709/http://www.cbc.ca/fifth/martin/scandal.html|archive-date=3 November 2012|dead-url=yes}}</ref>
The son of the day care owner was tried and found guilty, then a [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] task force took over the investigation. It concluded the original investigation was motivated by "emotional hysteria."<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Policeman gets $1.3 million in Martensville settlement |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2002/06/18/popowich020618.html |quote=Travis Sterling, son of the day care's owners, was convicted of two counts of sexual assault. He was the only person convicted. ... Early reports of the case suggested the alleged abuse was part of a satanic ritual, but after an RCMP task force took over the investigation, it concluded the original investigation was motivated by "emotional hysteria." |work=[[CBC News]] |date=2002-06-19 |accessdate=2009-02-06 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090304003428/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2002/06/18/popowich020618.html |archivedate=4 March 2009 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> In 2003, defendants sued for wrongful prosecution.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Wrongly accused in ritual abuse case launch $10 million suit |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2003/09/09/abuse_suit030909.html |quote= |publisher=[[CBC News]] |date=2003-09-09 |accessdate=2008-09-29 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090304003433/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2003/09/09/abuse_suit030909.html |archivedate=4 March 2009 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> In 2004, Richard and Kari Klassen received $100,000 each, out of the $1.5 million compensation package awarded for the malicious prosecution.<ref>{{cite news |title=Settlement details released for Sask. couple accused of child abuse |publisher=[[CBC News]] |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2004/11/18/klassen041118.html |quote=Richard and Kari Klassen received $100,000 each, a share of a $1.5 million compensation package for malicious prosecution. |date=2004-11-19 |accessdate=2008-10-03 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090304002941/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2004/11/18/klassen041118.html |archivedate=4 March 2009 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>

Some scholars continue to take the view that these cases were genuine and involved actual ritual abuse (Faller, 1996; Summit, 1994). However, skepticism has become widespread among research psychologists. Whether in Bakersfield (California), Jordan (Minnesota), Edenton, (North Carolina), Martensville (Canada) or Wenatchee (Washington), the affair generally began with a limited, plausible allegation... in the ensuing investigation, interrogation of child "victims" produced evidence that far more abuse had occurred than originally thought, and ultimately the compounding reports and rumors would implicate dozens of local residents in what could only be called sex rings or cults. Many social scientists, scholars, and legal authorities now view the stories of Satanic conspiracy that circulated in the 1980s as urban legends, and the daycare abuse cases as historical aberrations...
