{{redirect|Fossil hunter|the science fiction novel|Fossil Hunter}} {{refimprove|date=September 2010}} {{Paleontology}}
[[File:Sharksteeth-castlehain.jpg|thumb|Collecting [[Shark tooth|fossilized shark's teeth]] is an easy way to begin collecting fossils. They are often found in abundance on public beaches. The teeth shown here were collected in Castle Hayne, [[North Carolina]], and are from the [[Eocene]] and [[Cretaceous]] divisions.]] [[File:07PaleoFTb11.JPG|thumb|[[College of Wooster]] students collecting fossils as part of their invertebrate [[paleontology]] course. This is a roadside outcrop of [[Ordovician]] [[limestone]]s and [[shale]]s in southeastern [[Indiana]].]]
'''Fossil collecting''' (some times, in a non-scientific sense, '''fossil hunting''') is the [[Collecting|collection]] of [[fossils]] for scientific study, hobby, or profit. Fossil collecting, as practiced by amateurs, is the predecessor of modern [[paleontology]] and many still collect fossils and study fossils as amateurs. Professionals and amateurs alike collect fossils for their scientific value. A commercial trade in fossils has also long existed, with some of this being practised illegally.
==Process==
===Locating fossils===
====Rock type==== Fossils are generally found in [[sedimentary rock]] with differentiated strata<!--strata is plural of stratum--> representing a succession of deposited material.<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.sdnhm.org/kids/fossils/ffwhere.html | title=Where to look for fossils | publisher=San Diego Natural History Museum | accessdate=2007-09-06 }}</ref> The occurrence of fossil bearing material depends on environmental factors before and after the time of preservation. After death, the first preserving factor is a rapid burial in water bodies or [[Terrestrial ecoregion|terrestrial]] sediment which would help in preserving the specimen. These rocks types are usually termed [[clastic rock]], and are further subdivided into fine, medium and coarse grained material. While fossils can be found in all grain types, more detailed specimens are found in the fine grained material.<ref name=potts2003/> A second type of burial is the non-clastic rock, form where the rock is made up of the precipitation of compacted fossil material, types of rock include [[limestone]] and [[coal]]. The third fossil bearing material is the [[evaporates]], which precipitate out of concentrated dissolved salts to form [[Nodule (geology)|nodular deposit]]s, examples include [[rock salt]] and [[phosphate]] concentrations. The evaporates are usually associated with [[gastropod]], [[algae]], [[vertebrate]], and [[trace fossil]]s. Fossils are not to be found in areas of [[igneous rock]] (except in some beds between lava flows). In rocks which have undergone [[metamorphism]], fossils are generally so distorted that they are difficult to recognize or have been destroyed completely.<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.rasny.org/fossil/NYstrat.htm | title=Stratigraphy Fossil-Bearing Rocks | publisher=The Rochester Academy of Science | accessdate=2007-09-11 }}</ref>
====Preservation==== After burial various factors are at work to endanger the current fossil's preserved state. Chemical alteration would change the mineral composition of the fossil, but generally not its appearance, [[lithification]] would distort its appearance, the fossil itself may be fully or partially dissolved leaving only a fossil mold.<ref name=potts2003>{{Cite book|last=Potts |first=Joanna |editor-link=Joanna Potts|year=2003 |title=Guide to Fossils |location=London |publisher=Phillips|pages=31–34pp |isbn=0-540-08374-7}}</ref><ref name="How to look for fossils">{{Cite web| url=http://www.sdnhm.org/kids/fossils/ffmore.html | title=How to look for fossils | publisher=San Diego Natural History Museum | accessdate=2007-09-06 }}</ref>
====Exposure==== Areas where sedimentary rocks are being eroded include exposed [[mountain]]ous areas, [[river bank]]s and [[river bed|beds]], wave washed sea [[cliff]]s, and engineering features like [[Quarry|quarries]] and [[Cut (earthmoving)|road cuts]]. [[Coal mining]] operations often yield excellent fossil [[plant]]s, but the best ones are to be found not in the [[coal]] itself but in the associated sedimentary rock deposits called [[coal measures]].
Wave-washed sea cliffs and foreshore exposures are often good places to search for fossils, but always be aware of the state of the [[tide]]s in the area. Never take chances by climbing high cliffs of crumbling rock or clay (many have died attempting it). Dried up natural lake beds <ref>{{Cite web| url=http://acl.arts.usyd.edu.au/research/cuddie/cuddie.html | title=Dinnertime at Cuddie Springs: hunting and butchering megafauna? | publisher=Judith Furby, School of Archaeology, The University of Sydney, NSW 2006 | accessdate=2007-09-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071114003012/http://acl.arts.usyd.edu.au/research/cuddie/cuddie.html |archivedate = 2007-11-14}}</ref> and caves in the form of [[pitfall trap]]s <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.parks.sa.gov.au/naracoorte/caves/index.htm |title=Development of the Naracoorte Caves |publisher=South Australian Parks Web |accessdate=2007-09-11 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070901122951/http://www.parks.sa.gov.au/naracoorte/caves/index.htm |archivedate=2007-09-01 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> frequently also have high concentrations of fossils (e.g., [[Cuddie Springs]] and [[Naracoorte Caves]] in Australia).
Generally in appearance, a fossil will be either a different colour to the surrounding rock, because of the different mineral content, will have a defining shape and texture or a combination of both. A fossil can also be extracted from it's geological environment, having similar characteristics in colour naturally embed from the sedimentary formation (surrounding rock) it was found within.<ref name="How to look for fossils"/>
===Collecting techniques=== The techniques used to collect fossils vary depending on the sediment or rock in which the fossils are to be found. For collecting in rock a [[geological hammer]], a variety of [[Chisel#Cold chisel|cold chisel]]s and a [[mallet]] are used to split and break rocks to reveal fossils. Since the rock is deposited in layers, these layers may be split apart to reveal fossils. For soft [[sediment]]s and unconsolidated deposits, such as sands, [[silt]]s, and clays, a [[spade]], flat-bladed [[trowel]], and stiff [[brushes]] are used. [[Sieve]]s in a variety of [[mesh]] sizes are used to separate fossils from sands and [[gravel]]s. Sieving is a rougher technique for collecting fossils and can destroy fragile ones. Some times, water is run through a sieve to help remove silt and sand. This technique is called '''wet sieving'''
Fossils tend to be very fragile and are generally not extracted entirely from the surrounding rock (the matrix) in the field. Cloth, cotton, small boxes and aluminum foil are frequently used to protect fossils being transported. Occasionally, large fragile specimens may need to be protected and supported using a jacket of [[plaster]] before their removal from the rock. If a fossil is to be left [[in situ]], a cast may be produced, using [[plaster of paris]] or [[latex]]. Whilst not preserving every detail, such a cast is inexpensive, easier to transport, causes less damage to the environment, and leaves the fossil in place for others to enjoy. Fossilized [[Animal tracks|tracks]] are frequently documented with casts. Subtle fossils which are preserved solely as impressions in sandy layers, such as the [[Ediacaran biota|Ediacaran fossils]], are also usually documented by means of a cast, which shows detail more clearly than the rock itself.
Safety is emphasized while fossil collecting and [[hard hat]]s, safety [[goggle]]s, steel toe [[boot]]s, and protective [[glove]]s are used.
===Preparation and cleaning=== Sometimes, for smaller fossils, a stiff brush may simply be used to dust off and clean the fossil. For larger fossils, a chisel can be used to remove large bits of dirt, however, you run the risk of damaging the fossil. Running water can cause some types of fossils to either dislodge from the rock, or even crumble and break apart, for they are very fragile. Dental tools are sometimes used to remove small amounts of rock from the fossil.
===Documentation=== A knowledge of the precise location a fossil is essential if the fossil is to have any scientific value. Details of the parent rock strata, the location of the find, and other fossil material associated with the find help scientists to place the fossil in context, in terms of the time, location and situation in which the organism lived.<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.sdnhm.org/kids/fossils/ffwhat.html | title=Discover what you have | publisher=San Diego Natural History Museum | accessdate=2007-09-06 }}</ref> [[Data logging|Data logs]], photographs, and sketchs may accompany detailed field notes to assist in the locating of a fossiliferous outcrop. Individual fossils are ideally [[Database catalog|cataloged]] with a locality number and a unique specimen number. This allows a collection to be easily searched and specimens located. Catologing of collections is almost universal in large institutions like [[museums]].
==Collecting ethics== To collect fossils, there are various legal realities that must be observed. Permission should be sought before collection begins on private land.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ology.amnh.org/paleontology/stuff/findfossils_2.html |title=Do's and don'ts for fossil hunters |publisher=American Museum of Natural History |accessdate=2007-09-06 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070810175630/http://ology.amnh.org/paleontology/stuff/findfossils_2.html |archivedate=2007-08-10 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Hammering the rocks in [[national parks]] and other areas of natural beauty is often discouraged and in most cases is illegal.
The first expressly worded fossil-collecting code was published from the museum-home of pioneering geologist [[Hugh Miller]] at [[Cromarty]], on the Highland east coast of [[Scotland]], 11 April 2008. It was introduced by [[Michael Russell (politician)|Michael Russell]], [[Minister for Environment|Minister for Environment, Scotland]], as part of celebrations honouring the bicentennial of the founding of the [[Geological Society of London]]. The code supplements an existing draft drawn up by [[English Nature]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.english-nature.org.uk/news/statement.asp?Id=13 |title=English nature's code of collecting |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020114135719/http://www.english-nature.org.uk/news/statement.asp?ID=13 |archivedate=January 14, 2002}}</ref>
The code advises fossil collectors to seek permission from landowners, to collect responsibly, record details, seek advice on finding an unusual fossil and label the specimens and care for them. Its principles establish a framework of advice on best practices in the collection, identification, conservation and storage of fossil specimens.
The non-binding [[Ethical code|code of ethics]] for this field was drawn up by [[Scottish Natural Heritage]] (SNH) following many months of consultation with fossil collectors, landowners, palaeontological researchers, and staff of Scotland's museums.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://geology.com/news/2007/fossil-collectors-code-of-conduct.shtml |title=Geology.com: an early draft of the full code |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070624120211/http://geology.com/news/2007/fossil-collectors-code-of-conduct.shtml |archivedate=June 24, 2007}}</ref>
===Fossil trade=== [[Image:TBataar.jpeg|left|thumb|A ''[[Tarbosaurus]]'' specimen that was illegally smuggled to the US, and subsequently returned to Mongolia]] Fossil trading is the practice of buying and selling fossils. This is illegal when it comes to stolen fossils, and some important scientific specimens are sold to collectors, rather than given or obtained by museums and institutes of study.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/fossil-theft-one-of-our-dinosaurs-is-missing-1826931.html | work=The Independent | location=London | title=Fossil theft: One of our dinosaurs is missing | first=Cahal | last=Milmo | date=2009-11-25 | accessdate=2010-05-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://science.nationalgeographic.com/science/prehistoric-world/fossil-wars.html|title=Fossil Wars|last=Simons|first=Lewis|work=National Geographic|publisher=The [[National Geographic Society]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/catalyst/stories/s532586.htm|title=Fossil Trade|work=Catalyst|date=18 April 2002|author=Willis, Paul|author2=Clark, Tim|author3=Dennis, Carina}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=148688&sectioncode=26|title=Cretaceous crimes that fuel the fossil trade|last=Farrar|first=Steve|date=5 November 1999|work=Times Higher Education|accessdate=2 November 2011}}</ref> Much focus has been put on the illegal fossil dealing in [[China]], where many specimens have been stolen.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/www/english/language/bilingual/2009-11/483395.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100811070718/http://www.globaltimes.cn/www/english/language/bilingual/2009-11/483395.html |archivedate=August 11, 2010 |title=Fossil trade puts China's natural history at risk}}</ref> The trade is lucrative, and many celebrities collect fossils.<ref>{{citation|title=Luxury Market For Dinosaur Remains Thrives|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/09/luxury-dinosaur-market-th_n_1084588.html|publisher=The Huffington Post|date=10 November 2010|accessdate=21 May 2012}}</ref>
The [[Society of Vertebrate Paleontology]], an international association of professional and amateur vertebrate paleontologists, believes that scientifically important fossils—especially but not exclusively those found on public lands—should be held in perpetuity in the public trust, preferably in a museum or research institution, where they can benefit the scientific community as a whole as well as future generations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://vertpaleo.org/society/polstatvertfossilsale.cfm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100714230458/https://www.vertpaleo.org/society/polstatvertfossilsale.cfm |archivedate=July 14, 2010 |title=Statement regarding the sale of vertebrate fossils online}}</ref> In the United States, [[Paleontological Resources Preservation Act. S. 546]] and H. R. 2416 were introduced in the [[US Congress]] with SVP's full support.
Many commercial fossil collectors and dealers believe that such policies are a breach of their rights. The argument has also been put forth that there are too few professional paleontologists to collect and preserve fossils currently exposed to the elements, and that it is therefore essential that private citizens be allowed to collect them for the sake of their preservation. Eric Scott, the Curator of Paleontology for the San Bernardino County Museum, argues that 1) private citizens and amateur (not for profit) collectors can and do participate frequently in the permitted recovery and preservation of significant vertebrate fossils, and 2) preservation of significant fossils does not require or mandate ''sale'' of those fossils.<ref name="Scott2005">{{cite journal | author = Scott, E. | year = 2005 | title = Is Selling Vertebrate Fossils Bad For Science? | journal = PALAIOS| doi = 10.2110/palo.2005.S06 | volume = 20 | issue = 6 | pages = 515–517}}</ref>
According to the ethics by-law of SVP, "The barter, sale, or purchase of scientifically significant vertebrate fossils is not condoned, unless it brings them into or keeps them within a public trust."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vertpaleo.org/Content/NavigationMenu/TheSociety/StatementsandGuidelines/OntheSaleofVertebrateFossils/default.htm|title=Statement regarding the sale of vertebrate fossils online|publisher=The Society of Vertebrate Paleontology|accessdate=2 November 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403072414/http://www.vertpaleo.org/Content/NavigationMenu/TheSociety/StatementsandGuidelines/OntheSaleofVertebrateFossils/default.htm|archivedate=3 April 2012|df=}}</ref>
==Societies and clubs== Many include fossil collectors. [[Lapidary club]]s also include fossil collectors. In addition, paleontological societies and fossil clubs exist. There is some overlap between fossil collecting, [[mineral collecting]], and [[amateur geology]].
==Notable fossil collectors== [[File:Mary Anning painting.jpg|thumb|upright|Mary Anning, a famous collector and seller of fossils]] {{expand section|date=November 2010}} *[[Mary Anning]] *[[Robert Bakker]] *[[Edward Drinker Cope]] *[[Phil Currie]] *[[Othniel Charles Marsh]] *[[Paul Sereno]] *[[Charles Hazelius Sternberg]] *[[Peter Larson]] *[[Wolfgang Grulke]] *[[Triebold Paleontology Incorporated]] *Suresh Chopane, Maharashtra, India
==See also== * [[Fossil park]] * [[Lapidary club]] * [[List of fossil sites]] * [[Mineral collecting]] * [[National Fossil Day]] * [[Paleontologist]] * [[Paleozoology]] * [[Prehistoric life]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * [[Adrienne Mayor]], ''The First Fossil Hunters: Paleontology in Greek and Roman Times'' (Princeton University Press 2000) — {{ISBN|0-691-08977-9}} * Adrienne Mayor, ''Fossil Legends of the First Americans'' (Princeton University Press 2005) — {{ISBN|0-691-11345-9}}
==External links== * [http://www.fossilsites.com/ List of fossil localities in the United States and Canada] * [http://www.english.fossiel.net/ Fossil collecting locations in Europe and the rest of the World] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090303214207/http://mookychick.co.uk/lists/how_to_go_fossil_hunting.php Fossil hunting for beginners] * [http://inyo.coffeecup.com/site/manix/manixmypages.html Virtual Field Trips To Fossil-Bearing Areas] The virtual field trips include detailed text, images of representative fossils, plus on-site photographs. * [http://www.fossilguy.com/sites/index.htm Fossil collecting sites in the United States with very detailed information and directions]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fossil Collecting}} [[Category:Collecting]] [[Category:Fossils]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox boxer | name = Gerry Peñalosa | image = Gerry Penalosa.jpg | caption = Peñalosa in 2008 | realname = Geronimo Peñalosa | nickname = Fearless | weight = {{plainlist| *[[Light flyweight]] *[[Super flyweight]] *[[Bantamweight]] *[[Super bantamweight]] }} | height = 5 ft 4 in | reach = 65 in | nationality = [[Philippines|Filipino]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1972|8|7}} | birth_place = [[San Carlos City, Negros Occidental|San Carlos City]],
[[Negros Occidental]],
Philippines | style = [[Southpaw stance|Southpaw]] | total = 65 | wins = 55 | KO = 37 | losses = 8 | draws = 2 }} '''Geronimo''' "'''Gerry'''" '''Peñalosa''' (born August 7, 1972) is a [[Philippines|Filipino]] former [[professional boxer]] who competed from 1989 to 2010. He is a two-weight world champion, having held the [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] and [[lineal championship|lineal]] [[super flyweight]] titles from 1997 to 1998, and the [[World Boxing Organization|WBO]] [[bantamweight]] title from 2007 to 2009. Originally from [[San Carlos City, Negros Occidental|San Carlos City]], Peñalosa currently resides in [[Manila]]. He was trained mainly by [[Freddie Roach (boxing)|Freddie Roach]], and went on to become a boxing trainer himself after retirement. Peñalosa's older brother, [[Dodie Boy Peñalosa]], is also a former boxer and world champion. ==Professional career== ===Early years at flyweight=== Peñalosa turned professional in 1989. He made his debut against Fidel Jubay on May 20, 1989, and won the bout by knockout. ===Super flyweight=== He captured the WBC and [[Lineal championship|lineal]] super flyweight title with a decision win over [[Hiroshi Kawashima]] on 27 February 1997 and has defended the title three times since then.{{cite web|url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/jrbant.htm|title=Gerry Peñalosa - Lineal Jr. Bantamweight Champion|publisher=The Cyber Boxing Zone Encyclopedia}} He later lost it on points to [[In-Joo Cho]] on 29 August 1998. Two years later, he had a rematch with Cho to regain the title but again lost by controversial unanimous decision. ===Retirement and comeback=== On 24 September 2001, he challenged [[Masamori Tokuyama]] who then succeeded Cho in being the WBC super flyweight champion. However, he lost by another controversial split decision. The two fought again on 20 December 2002 but the result was the same, in Tokuyama's favor. Peñalosa temporarily retired that year. Peñalosa returned to boxing two years later. He defeated Bangsaen Sithpraprom for the World Boxing Foundation (WBFo) super flyweight title on 7 November 2004. ===Super bantamweight=== On 17 March 2007, he took on [[Daniel Ponce de León]] who then held the WBO super bantamweight title. In the fight, Peñalosa displayed his intelligence, excellent boxing skills and defensive abilities. De León who is a knockout artist could not land a clear punch on Penalosa. Penalosa answered with stinging counters that frustrated De Leon. Although De Leon was the busier boxer, most of his punches landed in the air and on Penalosa's gloves. However, De Leon won via unanimous decision. ===Return to bantamweight=== ====WBO champion==== On August 11, 2007, the veteran Filipino boxer took on [[Jhonny González]] of [[Mexico]] for the WBO bantamweight title at the Arco Arena in [[Sacramento, California]], [[California]].{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Mexican fighters to stake titles vs Filipinos in US | work = | publisher =GMANews.TV | date =2007-06-14 | url =http://www.gmanews.tv/story/46502/mexican-fighters-to-stake-titles-vs-filipinos-in-us}} Peñalosa went down in weight and dethroned the Mexican fighter at the 7th round. The younger fighter appeared to be in control of the match in the early rounds, as he skillfully kept the much shorter Peñalosa away with crisp jabs. Peñalosa stayed patient and continued to walk forward even though he is getting hit by some of the Mexican's punches. In the seventh round, Peñalosa got an opportunity, when Gonzales launched a strong right that missed Peñalosa head. Gonzalez failed to pull his arm back quickly and at that short moment, leaving a hole for the veteran fighter, who then threw a precise and solid left hook to Gonzalez’ body. The defending champion fell on the canvas a few moments after receiving the counter-attack; the Mexican tried to get up and fight again but failed to do it remained down on the canvas. This was Peñalosa's second world title in 10 years.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Gerry Penalosa – Beating the Boxing Odds | work = | publisher =eastsideboxing.com | date =2008-03-29 | url =http://www.eastsideboxing.com/news.php?p=15035&more=1}} He defended the title in [[Quezon City, Philippines]] by stopping former world title holder [[Ratanachai Sor Vorapin]] of [[Thailand]] in the eighth round on 6 April 2008.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Gerry Peñalosa remains WBO bantam champ | work = | publisher =abs-cbnNEWS.com | date =04-06-2008 | url =http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/sports/04/06/08/gerry-pe%C3%B1alosa-remains-wbo-bantam-champ}} This was the second time he fought Sor Vorapin in which Peñalosa prevailed on both encounters. On February 21, 2009, Peñalosa took on German Meraz of [[Mexico]] at the Cebu Coliseum in [[Cebu City]], [[Cebu]], Philippines; the two fought in the main event of the "Battle of the Bantamweights" card. The WBO title was not at stake. The Filipino boxer won the fight by unanimous decision after 10 rounds.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Peñalosa leads RP triumph in Battle of Bantamweights | work = | publisher =abs-cbnNEWS.com | date =2009-02-22 | url =http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/sports/04/06/08/gerry-pe%C3%B1alosa-remains-wbo-bantam-champ}} ====Events outside the ring==== After the Manny Pacquiao-Marco Antonio Barrera rematch in Las Vegas, Peñalosa and [[Jorge Arce]] of Mexico nearly figured in a fistfight, according to a report by Philboxing.com. The two boxers crossed their way out of the Mandalay Bay Events Center. The boxing website said its sources revealed that it was Arce who challenged Peñalosa to a fight. Peñalosa was reportedly with his wife Goody and Japanese associate Kosuke Washio when the incident happened. Arce was reportedly irritated when one spectator told him upon seeing Penalosa that the Filipino boxer is more popular than him. The proud Mexican, the report said, apparently did not like the comments and immediately confronted the Filipino world champion. According to the report, Peñalosa was apparently irked by Arce's actuations and tried to follow the Mexican boxer but was prevailed upon by Goody.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =RP's Gerry Penalosa, Mexico's Jorge Arce in near fistfight | work = | publisher =GMANEWS.com | date =2007-10-10 | url =http://www.gmanews.tv/story/63854/rp39s-gerry-penalosa-mexico39s-jorge-arce-in-near-fistfight}} ===Super bantamweight=== He later fought on 25 April 2009, in [[Puerto Rico]] against Puerto Rican sensation [[Juan Manuel López (boxer)|Juan Manuel López]] for the WBO Super Bantamweight Championship. The showdown featured as a '''Champion versus Champion''' match because the two fighters were both holders of WBO World titles. Penalosa had the bantamweight title and Lopez had the super bantamweight belt. Early in the fight, both pugilists exchanged combinations, with López gaining a slight advantage by targeting the head and body of Peñalosa. This pattern continued in the third and fourth rounds, while the challenger continued counterattacking despite receiving more damage. Between the fifth and sixth chapters, both pugilists exchanged combinations, with Peñalosa scoring his most solid punches. During the following two rounds, López managed to establish control of the offensive's tempo, but Peñalosa continued using his counterattack. Prior to the ninth chapter, Peñalosa's trainer, Freddie Roach, warned him that he had to win by knockout or the fight would be stopped. In the round, the pattern continued with few variations, once it was over Roach submitted the fight. With this technical knockout, López became the first boxer to defeat the veteran by knockout.{{cite web | last = | first = | author =Luis Cadiz | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Juanma: On The Brink! | work = | publisher =pound4pound.com | date = |url=http://www.pound4pound.com/FightReport/2009/JuanmaOnTheBrink.htm}} After the fight, the Filipino boxer said: "He (Lopez) was too big for me. I felt his punches. But I hope he wasn't lying after the fight when he said he felt my punches, too. I was the underdog but I gave it my best. I trained hard for that fight". Then Penalosa talked about a possible retirement after one last fight, as he wants to hang up his gloves as a champion. Many people, including members of his family and his friend, [[Manny Pacquiao]], wanted Peñalosa to quit boxing already, saying he has nothing more to prove in the sport.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Peñalosa: I’m still good for one last fight | work = | publisher =GMANews.TV | date =02-06-2009 | url =http://www.gmanews.tv/story/163821/pealosa-im-still-good-for-one-last-fight}}{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Pacquiao to pal Gerry: Time to hang up gloves | work = | publisher =GMANews.TV | date =2009-04-26 | url =http://www.gmanews.tv/story/158635/pacquiao-to-pal-gerry-time-to-hang-up-gloves}} In April, Penalosa was stripped of his bantamweight title for failing to defend it within one year.http://www.manilastandardtoday.com/?page=sports4_may18_2009 ====Farewell fights==== However, Peñalosa decided to fight for one more time. Many tough boxers were considered to be his possible next opponent, including [[Jorge Arce]], Daniel Ponce de Leon, [[Eric Morel]] and [[Vic Darchinyan]].{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Gerry Peñalosa sets his sights on Vic Darchinyan | work = | publisher =boxingscene.com | date =2009-07-18 | url =http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=21092}} On 13 February 2010, Peñalosa faced Eric Morel (41-2) of Puerto Rico for the interim WBO bantamweight title at the [[Las Vegas Hilton]] in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]]. The veteran fighter trained at the Wild Card Gym in Los Angeles under the guidance of coach Freddie Roach, along with Filipino prospect [[Bernabe Concepcion]] and [[Septuple champion|seven-division world champion]] [[Manny Pacquiao]].{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Gerry Peñalosa joins Manny Pacquiao at Wild Card Gym | work = | publisher =GMANews.TV | date =03-11-2009 | url =http://www.gmanews.tv/story/152233/gerry-pealosa-joins-manny-pacquiao-at-wild-card-gym}} The bout was part of the card named "Pinoy Power 3", in which four other Filipino boxers fought.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Filipino boxers aim for sweep in ‘Pinoy Power III’ | work = | publisher =abs-cbnNEWS.com | date =2010-02-14 | url =http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/sports/02/13/10/filipino-boxers-aim-sweep-%E2%80%98pinoy-power-iii%E2%80%99}} Peñalosa eventually lost the bout by a controversial Split Decision.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Bloodied Peñalosa bows to Morel | work = | publisher =GMANews.TV | date =2010-02-14 | url =http://www.gmanews.tv/story/183874/bloodied-pentildealosa-bows-to-morel}}{{cite web | last = | first = | author =Dan Rafael | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Morel handed title in dubious decision | work = | publisher =ESPN.com | date =2010-02-15 | url =http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/columns/story?columnist=rafael_dan&id=4915712}} At the opening round the Puerto Rican looked to stick and move while Peñalosa took on the role of the aggressor. In the early rounds Morel appeared a bit more active. Peñalosa received a bad low blow in the 2nd round and was given some time to recover. In the 6th round a clash of heads opened a cut over the Filipino's right eyes; a few moments later, another headbutt opened a severe laceration over Peñalosa's left eye. The injury bled profusely during the next rounds, but he was able to hurt the opponent with strong body punches and seemed to take control of the fight. With the bleeding clearly bothering him, the "Fearless" boxer continued to attack as Morel seemed to keep away from him. Peñalosa continued along this way through the championship rounds, while Morel looked to jab and retreat. During the last rounds, Peñalosa fought hard but apparently hadn't done enough to impress the judges.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Eric Morel beats Gerry Peñalosa, Split Decision Call | work = | publisher =boxingscene.com | date =2010-02-13 | url =http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=25351}} Two judges scored the fight 115-113 and 116-112 for Morel, while the third and final card scored the bout 113-115 for Peñalosa. FightFan.com had the bout scored 115-113 for Peñalosa.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Eric Morel edges a bloody good Gerry Penalosa! | work = | publisher =FightFan.com | date =2010-02-13 | url =http://fightfan.com/2010/02/eric-morel-edges-a-bloody-good-gerry-penalosa/}} Some people even said that the Filipino boxer should have won over the Puerto Rican, including his trainer, Freddie Roach, and Manny Pacquiao.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Peñalosa to release statement on career | work = | publisher =abs-cbnNEWS.com | date =03-01-2010 | url =http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/sports/03/01/10/pe%C3%B1alosa-release-statement-career}} Following the fight against Morel, Peñalosa stated that he will fight for one last time against Yodsaenkeng Kietmangmee of Thailand on October 10, 2010. The Filipino pugilist also revealed that the proceeds of this match will be given to Z Gorres to help him with his medical expenses.{{cite web | url =http://philboxing.com/news/story-44532.html | title =Gerry’s last hurrah for The Dream | last=Bonsubre | first =Rene | work = | publisher =PhilBoxing.com | date =September 27, 2010 | accessdate =October 10, 2010}} The event, called "Golpe Golpe na Zamboanga: The Last Hurrah", was held at the Zamboanga City Coliseum.{{cite web | url =http://philboxing.com/news/story-44981.html | title =All set for Gerry’s last fight | last=Pangilinan | first =Robbie | work = | publisher =PhilBoxing.com | date =October 9, 2010 | accessdate =October 10, 2010}} The former world champion won the bout by TKO in the 4th round.{{cite web | url =http://philboxing.com/news/story-45018.html | title =All set for Gerry’s last fight | last=Bonsubre | first =Rene | work = | publisher =PhilBoxing.com | date =October 10, 2010 | accessdate =October 10, 2010}} Peñalosa finished his 21-year career with a professional record of 55 wins, with 37 knockouts, 8 losses and 2 draws. ===Retirement=== After retiring as a fighter he became a boxing promoter with his nephew, Dave Peñalosa, among the boxers in his stable.{{cite web | url =http://combat-asia.com/index.php/gerry-penalosas-nephew-dave-penalosa-to-take-on-thai-opponent-in-manila-on-saturday| title =Gerry Peñalosa's nephew Dave Peñalosa to take on Thai opponent in Manila on Saturday| last= | first = | work = | publisher =Combat Asia | date =August 14, 2012 | accessdate =August 14, 2012}} ==Outside the ring== On April 21, 2008, Peñalosa won in the game show ''[[Wheel of Fortune (Philippine game show)|Wheel of Fortune]]'' held in the Philippines, defeating fellow boxers [[Reynaldo Bautista|Rey Bautista]] and [[AJ Banal|Alex John Banal]]. The prize he earned was worth [[Philippine peso|P]]159,000 ($3,791).{{cite web |url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/sports/04/22/08/pe%C3%B1alosa-enjoys-p159k-prize-wheel-fortune |title=Peñalosa enjoys P159K prize from Wheel of Fortune |date=April 22, 2008 |accessdate=2010-02-28 |author=Dyan Castillejo |publisher=abs-cbnnews.com }} Peñalosa served as the trainer of IBF flyweight champion [[Nonito Donaire]] in 2008.{{cite web |url=http://philboxing.com/news/story-21467.html |title=PENALOSA CONFIRMS HE'LL TRAIN DONAIRE |date=30 December 2008 |accessdate=2008-12-31 |author=Ronnie Nathanielsz |publisher=PhilBoxing.com }} ==Professional boxing record== {{BoxingRecordSummary |draws=2 |ko-wins=37 |ko-losses=1 |dec-wins=18 |dec-losses=7 }} {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:95%" |- !{{abbr|No.|Number}} !Result !Record !Opponent !Type !Round, time !Date !Location !Notes |- |65 |{{yes2}}Win |55–8–2 |style="text-align:left;"|{{flagicon|THA}} Anan Saeauy |TKO |4 (10), {{small|1:49}} |Oct 10, 2010 |style="text-align:left;"|{{flagicon|PHI}} {{small|[[Mayor Vitaliano D. {{Infobox civil conflict | title = Hong Kong 1956 riots | partof = | image = 1956riot 03.jpg | caption = Hong Kong police force dispatched its Anti-Riot Squad officers | place = [[Hong Kong]] | coordinates = | date = 10 October 1956 | status = Riots put down | side1 = * [[Pro-Beijing camp]] | side2 = * [[Pro-Taiwan camp]] | side3 = * [[Hong Kong Police]] '''Supported by:''' *[[British Forces Overseas Hong Kong]] | injuries = 500 | fatalities = 59 }}
{{Use Hong Kong English|date=February 2017}} {{Chinese|t=雙十暴動|l=[[Double Ten Day|Double Tenth]] riots|p=Shuāngshí Bàodòng|pic=1956riot 04.jpg|piccap=Riot photos}} The '''Hong Kong 1956 riots''' were the result of escalating provocations between pro-[[Chinese Nationalist|Nationalist]] and pro-[[Communist Party of China|Communist]] factions in Hong Kong during [[Double Ten Day]], 10 October 1956.<ref name="hkh1">HKheadline.com. "[http://news.hkheadline.com/figure/index.asp?page_f_id=1&id=108 HKheadline.com]." ''雙十暴動：香港最血腥的一天.'' Retrieved on 7 July 2010.</ref>
Most violence took place in the town of [[Tsuen Wan]], five miles from central Kowloon. A mob stormed and ransacked a clinic and welfare centre, killing four people. Some foreigners became involved, including a Swiss national who lost his life while travelling in a taxi on [[Nathan Road]].<ref name="Time">[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,824497,00.html "Hong Kong: Trouble on the Double Ten"], ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' Monday, 22 Oct. 1956</ref>
To quell the rioting, [[Chief Secretary for Administration|Colonial Secretary]] [[Edgeworth B. David]] ordered extra manpower from the [[British Forces Overseas Hong Kong|British Forces Hong Kong]], including armoured troops of [[The Queen's Royal Hussars|7th Hussars]], to reinforce the [[Hong Kong Police]] and disperse the rioters.<ref name="Time"/> In total, there were 59 deaths and approximately 500 injuries. Property damage was estimated at US$1,000,000.<ref name="hkh1" /><ref>Chu, Yingchi. [2003] (2003). Hong Kong Cinema: Coloniser, Motherland and Self. Routledge publishing. {{ISBN|0-7007-1746-3}}</ref>
In the subsequent trials four people were convicted of murder and given death penalties.
