revision.text:
{{Infobox animal | name = Master McGrath | image = MasterMcGrathLurgan.JPG | image_size = | caption = Bronze sculpture of Master McGrath in [[Lurgan]], Co. Armagh | birth_name = | othername = Dicksy | species = ''[[Dog|Canis lupus familiaris]]'' | breed = [[Greyhound]] | gender = Male | birth_date = 1866 | birth_place = Colligan Lodge
[[County Waterford]], [[Ireland]] | death_date = 1873 | death_place = | resting_place = [[Lurgan]], [[County Armagh]] | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = | occupation = | employer = | role = | years_active = | known = [[Hare coursing]] | tricks = | awards = [[Waterloo Cup]] | title = | term = 1868, 1869 and 1871 | predecessor = | successor = | owner = [[Charles Brownlow, 2nd Baron Lurgan|The 2nd Baron Lurgan]] | parents = | children = | weight = 24 kg (53 lb) | height = | appearance = Black and white | namedafter = | website = }} '''Master McGrath''' (1866–1873) was a famous [[Greyhound]] in the sport of [[hare coursing]].https://www.discoverireland.ie/Arts-Culture-Heritage/master-mcgrath-monument/49822https://greytarticles.wordpress.com/historical/master-mcgrath-ireland%E2%80%99s-famous-coursing-greyhound/ ==Early days== Master McGrath was born in [[County Waterford]], [[Ireland]]. A small, weak pup, he went on to become the most celebrated and successful dog of his time. Master McGrath was born in 1866 at Colligan Lodge, the home of James Galwey, a well-known trainer and owner of [[greyhound]]s. Master McGrath was one of a litter of seven pups and although small was powerfully built. As a pup, his pet name was "Dicksy". ==First trial== The dog showed none of the outstanding qualities which were later to make him famous at his first trial; his performance was so bad that his trainer ordered him to be given away. As luck would have it his "slipper" (handler) took charge of him and having more faith in him, entered him in several courses which he won. After these wins, he was returned to his trainer. ==Waterloo Cup== He won the [[Waterloo Cup]] on three occasions, 1868, 1869 and 1871, and was the first greyhound to do so. He became such a [[celebrity]] that his owner, [[Charles Brownlow, 2nd Baron Lurgan|The 2nd Baron Lurgan]], was asked to take him to be seen by [[Queen Victoria]] and the [[British Royal Family]]. His success enabled Lord Lurgan to build a terrace of houses in [[Walthamstow]] from Master McGrath's winnings. These houses now form part of Shernhall Street, but are still clearly marked at one end of the terrace as "Master McGrath Terrace". ==Death== Master McGrath died early in 1873 of [[heart disease]] which had already ended his career as a sire.{{cite news|first=P. J.|last=McConville|title=The Wonder Dog – Master McGrath|newspaper=[[Lurgan Mail]]|date=1941-12-27}} An [[autopsy]] showed that his heart was twice the size of a normal dog's heart. He was buried in the grounds of a house called "Solitude" in [[Lurgan]]. The house has since been demolished for development and Master McGrath's grave lies at a house once owned by an early English settler. ==Information== *'''Name:''' Master McGrath *'''Pet Name:''' Dicksy *'''Color:''' BKW *'''Sex:''' male *'''Weight:''' 24 kg (53 lb) *'''Date Of Birth:'''1866 *'''Land Of Birth:''' [[Ireland]] *'''Breeder:''' James Galway Waterford *'''Owner:''' [[Charles Brownlow, 2nd Baron Lurgan|Lord Lurgan]] ==Song and Ballad – ''Master McGrath''== Eighteen sixty eight being the date and the year,
Those Waterloo sportsmen and more did appear;
For to gain the great prizes and bear them awa',
Never counting on Ireland and Master McGrath. On the twelfth of December, that day of renown,
McGrath and his keeper they left Lurgan town;
A gale in the Channel, it soon drove them o'er,
On the thirteenth they landed on fair England's shore. And when they arrived there in big London town,
Those great English sportsmen all gathered round -
And one of the gentlemen gave a "Ha! Ha!" Saying,
"Is that the great dog you call Master McGrath?" And one of those gentlemen standing around
Says, "I don't care a damn for your Irish greyhound,"
And another he laughs with a scornful "Ha! Ha!
We'll soon humble the pride of your Master McGrath." Then Lord Lurgan stepped forward and said, "Gentlemen,
If there's any among you has money to spend -
For your grand english nobles I don't care a straw -
Here's five thousand to one upon Master McGrath." Then McGrath he looked up and he wagged his old tail,
Informing his lordship, "I know what you mane,
Don't fear, noble Brownlow, don't fear them, agra,
For I'll tarnish their laurels," says Master McGrath. And Rose stood uncovered, the great English pride,
Her master and keeper were close by her side;
They have let her away and the crowd cried "Hurrah!"
For the pride of all England – and Master McGrath. As Rose and the Master they both ran along,
"Now I wonder," says Rose, "what took you from your home;
You should have stayed there in your Irish domain,
And not come to gain laurels on Albion's plain." "Well, I know," says McGrath, "we have wild heather bogs
But you'll find in old Ireland there's good men and dogs.
Lead on, bold Britannia, give none of your jaw,
Stuff that up your nostrils," says Master McGrath. Then the hare she went on just as swift as the wind
He was sometimes before her and sometimes behind.
Rose gave the first turn according to law;
But the second was given by Master McGrath. The hare she led on with a wonderful view.
And swift as the wind o'er the green field she flew.
But he jumped on her back and he held up his paw
"Three cheers for old Ireland," says Master McGrath. I've known many greyhounds that filled me with pride,
In the days that are gone, but it can't be denied,
That the greatest and the bravest that the world ever saw,
Was our champion of champions, great Master McGrath. There was also a tune; "The Master McGrath Gallop" by H. R. Callcott R.A.M. (Composer of The Massereene Waltzes) ==Honours== *Waterloo Cup 1868, 1869, 1871 ==External links== *[https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/flyingkiwi_2000/mcgrath.htm&date=2009-10-25+22:16:06 Information on the famous greyhoud-Master McGrath] *[http://www.greyhound-data.com/d?i=144756 Information and pictures on Master McGrath] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060327012400/http://sniff.numachi.com/~rickheit/dtrad/pages/tiMASMCGR%3BttMASMCGR.html ''Master McGrath''] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Greyhound racing]] [[Category:Individual dogs]] [[Category:1866 animal births]] [[Category:1871 animal deaths]] [[Category:Individual animals in Ireland]]

'''Melchisedek Tsouderos''' ({{lang-el|Μελχισεδέκ Τσουδερός}}; 1769-1823) was a [[Greeks|Greek]] monk and fighter of the [[Greek War of Independence]] from [[Crete]]. He was killed in 1823 in a battle with the Ottoman forces.
==Biographical information== He was born in 1769.<ref>''Σύγχρονος Εγκυκλοπαίδεια Ελευθερουδάκη'', vol. 23, p. 363.</ref> His name was Michael and he had origins from the historic [[Tsouderos]] family. He was the third son of Emmanouil Tsouderos and had three more brothers named Georgios, Ioannis and Nikolaos.<ref name=Kokkinos>Dionysios Kokkinos, Η Ελληνική Επανάστασις, εκδόσεις Μέλισσα, Athens 1974, 6th edition, vol 2, p. 14.</ref><ref>Anastasios N. Goudas, Βιογραφία Τσουδερών ή Καλλεργών, Τυπογραφείον "Εστία", Athens, 1930, p. 53 - 54.</ref> In 1810 he became a monk with the [[monastic name]] Melchisedek in [[Preveli Monastery]], which had conceded properties of his family. Around the 1817 he became abbot of the monastery acquiring the nickname "Tsouderogoumenos" ("Abbot Tsouderos").<ref name=Goudas54>Goudas, 1930, p. 54.</ref> During the pre-revolutionary period he was initiated into the [[Filiki Eteria]] by a monk of [[Agia Lavra]].<ref name=Goudas54/>
During May 1821, as the [[Greek Revolution]] had broken out in mainland Greece, an [[Cretan Turks|Ottoman-Cretan]] officer tried to arrest him, but he was informed by another Ottoman-Cretan and fled to Asomatos in the [[Rethymno]] region. From there, he moved with his brothers Georgios and Ioannis to [[Kallikratis]] and then he went along with an armed force to the monastery, which in the meantime had been destroyed and looted by the Ottomans.<ref name=Kokkinos/> On the 24th of the same month, he attended the official declaration of the Revolution in Crete in [[Kourkoulo Rodakinou]].<ref>Goudas, 1930, p. 58.</ref>
On 13 June he participated in a battle on the hill of Agios Ioannis where a force of 600 Ottomans had camped. The surprise was absolute and the Ottomans suffered many losses – among the dead was their leader, the Ottoman-Cretan Ismail Agha or Psaraosmailis – and they retreated while the rebels took over a number of villages. Two days later, his men prevailed in a new battle with enemy forces in Spili. From the Ottoman side, among the dead was Deli Mustafa, who was captured and later executed.<ref>Goudas, 1930, p. 60-63</ref>
In May 1822 Tsouderos participated in the Third Assembly of the Cretans, in [[Armenoi]] in Chania. He even took caregiver tasks under the command of the general prefect of Crete [[Michail Komninos Afentoulief]].<ref>Sp. Zampelios – K. Kritovoulidos, Ιστορία των Επαναστάσεων της Κρήτης - συμπληρωθείσα υπό Ιωάννου Δ. Κονδυλάκη, Δ.Φεξη, Athens, 1893, p. 416 - 418.</ref> He was killed in Polemarchi in Chania, on 3 February 1823, during the operations of the revolutionaries to capture the Kissamos Tower where the Ottoman forces were barricaded.<ref>Goudas, 1930, p. 63-64</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tsouderos}} [[Category:1823 deaths]] [[Category:1769 births]] [[Category:People of the Greek War of Independence]] [[Category:Members of the Filiki Eteria]] [[Category:People from Crete]] [[Category:People killed in action]] [[Category:Greek Christian monks]] [[Category:Greek abbots]]

page.title: Migrant deaths along the Mexico–United States border

revision.text:
[[Image:No Vale La Pena.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Border Patrol sign in Spanish, in California warning "Caution! Do not expose your life to the elements. It's not worth it!"]]
'''Migrant deaths along the Mexico–U.S. border''' occur hundreds of times a year because of those attempting to cross into the [[United States]] from [[Mexico]] illegally.<ref>United States Government Accounting Office. [http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d06770.pdf GAO-06-770], August 2006.</ref> The US Border Patrol reported 294 migrant deaths in the fiscal year 2017 (ending September 30, 2017), which was lower than in 2016 (322), and any year during the period 2003-2014. The highest number of deaths reported over the period 1998-2016 were the 492 deaths reported by the Border Patrol in 2005.<ref>US Border Patrol, [https://www.cbp.gov/sites/default/files/assets/documents/2016-Oct/BP%20Southwest%20Border%20Sector%20Deaths%20FY1998%20-%20FY2016.pdf Southwest border deaths by fiscal year 2016] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170521032543/https://www.cbp.gov/sites/default/files/assets/documents/2016-Oct/BP%20Southwest%20Border%20Sector%20Deaths%20FY1998%20-%20FY2016.pdf |date=2017-05-21 }}, accessed 25 July 2017.</ref><ref name=":0">U.S. Border Patrol, [https://www.cbp.gov/sites/default/files/assets/documents/2017-Dec/BP%20Southwest%20Border%20Sector%20Deaths%20FY1998%20-%20FY2017.pdf], accessed 13 December 2017.</ref> Exposure (including [[hyperthermia|heat stroke]], [[dehydration]], and [[hyperthermia]]) were the leading cause.<ref name="Eschbach01">Eschbach, K., J. Hagan and N. Rodriguez (2001): [https://web.archive.org/web/20070926034617/http://www.uh.edu/cir/Causes_and_Trends.pdf Causes and Trends in Migrant Deaths Along the U.S.–Mexico Border 1985–1998]. Center for Immigration Research, University of Houston ([https://web.archive.org/web/20071120014953/http://www.uh.edu/cir/Executive_Summary.pdf Executive Summary]).</ref>
The group [[Border Angels]] estimates that since 1994, about 10,000 people have died in their attempt to cross the increasingly militarized border.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.borderangels.org/about-us/|title=About Us – Border Angels|publisher=}}</ref> According to the [[U.S. Customs and Border Protection]], 7,216 people have died crossing the [[Mexico–United States border|U.S–Mexico border]] between 1998 and 2017.<ref name=":0" /> In 2005, more than 500 died across the entire U.S.–Mexico border.<ref>PBS Frontline (June 27, 2006): [https://www.pbs.org/frontlineworld/blog/2006/06/usmexico_border_1.html U.S.-Mexico Border: The Season of Death]</ref> The number of yearly border crossing deaths doubled from 1995 to 2005, before declining.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d06770.pdf |title=GAO-06-770 Illegal Immigration: Border-Crossing Deaths Have Doubled Since 1995 |publisher=United States Government Accountability Office |date=August 2006 |format=PDF}}</ref> The statistics reflect only known deaths and do not include those who have never been found.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.azdhs.gov/phs/borderhealth/pdf/newsletter2_3.pdf | title=Unauthorized Border Crosser Death along the Arizona/ Sonora border | publisher=Arizona Department of Health Services |date=June 2007|format=PDF}}</ref>
Mexico's [[Secretary of Foreign Affairs (Mexico)|Secretariat of Foreign Affairs]] has compiled data including deaths on the Mexican side of the border area during the period from 1994 to 2000. The data shows 87 deaths in 1996, 149 in 1997, 329 in 1998, 358 in 1999, and 499 in 2000.<ref>Wayne A. Cornelius (2001): [https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20071025202011/http://www.ccis-ucsd.org/PUBLICATIONS/wrkg27.PDF Death at the Border: The Efficacy and “Unintended” Consequences of U.S. Immigration Control Policy 1993–2000]. The Center for Comparative Immigration Studies University of California, San Diego.</ref>
U.S. Border Patrol reported that 3,221 migrants were rescued in the fiscal year 2017.<ref name=":0"/>
==Arizona==
The ''[[Arizona Daily Star]]'' maintained a database of border deaths recorded by the Pima, Santa Cruz, Cochise, and Yuma County medical examiners between summer 2004 and September 2006.<ref>''Arizona Daily Star'' [http://regulus.azstarnet.com/borderdeaths/search.php Border Death Database] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106163958/http://regulus.azstarnet.com/borderdeaths/search.php |date=2010-01-06 }}</ref> They stated, "With no official record-keeping system, the exact number of [[illegal entry|illegal entrants]] who have died along the Arizona stretch of U.S-Mexican border has never been known".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://regulus.azstarnet.com/borderdeaths/search.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-02-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106163958/http://regulus.azstarnet.com/borderdeaths/search.php |archivedate=2010-01-06 |df= }}, retrieved 14 May 2006</ref>
The number of dead border crossing migrants per year in Arizona increased from nine in 1990 to 201 in 2005; about 80% of the dead migrants were under 40 during 2000–2005, with an increasing number younger than 18.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/texassouthwest/stories/021607dntexazdead.149bf0e.html# | title=Funnel effect blamed for leap in border deaths | author=Isabel C. Morales | publisher=[[Dallas Morning News]] | date=2007-02-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.immigrationpolicy.org/images/File/brief/Crisis%20at%20the%20Border.pdf |title=A Humanitarian Crisis at the Border: New Estimates of Deaths Among Unauthorized Immigrants |author1=Raquel Rubio-Goldsmith |author2=M. Melissa McCormick |author3=Daniel Martinez |author4=Inez Magdalena Duarte |publisher=Immigration Policy Center |year=2007 |format=pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090506223329/http://www.immigrationpolicy.org/images/File/brief/Crisis%20at%20the%20Border.pdf |archivedate=2009-05-06 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://immigration.server263.com/images/File/brief/Full%20BMI%20Report.pdf |title=The "Funnel Effect" & Recovered Bodies of Unauthorised Migrants Processed by the Pima County Office of the Medical Examiner, 1990–2005 |author1=Raquel Rubio-Goldsmith |author2=M. Melissa McCormick |author3=Daniel Martinez |author4=Inez Magdalena Duarte |publisher=Binational Migration Institute, Mexican American Studies & Research Center at the University of Arizona |date=October 2006|format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090704163934/http://immigration.server263.com/images/File/brief/Full%20BMI%20Report.pdf |archivedate=2009-07-04 |df= }}</ref>
==Trends== [[File:Border Wall at Tijuana and San Diego Border.jpg|thumb|[[:en:Mexico–United States barrier|Mexico–United States barrier]] at the border of [[:en:Tijuana|Tijuana, Mexico]] and [[:en:San Diego|San Diego, USA]]. The crosses represent migrants who have died in crossing attempts. Some who are identified, some not. Surveillance tower in the background.]] A study by the [https://web.archive.org/web/20100621092232/http://www.class.uh.edu/cir/index.asp Center for Immigration Research] at the [[University of Houston]] found that, "In the late 1980s, the number of foreign transient deaths usually exceeded 300, and peaked in 1988 at 355. Thereafter, the number of deaths fell to 180 in 1993 and 1994. After 1994 the number of deaths started to increase again, peaking in 2000 at 370. Border Patrol counts for 2001 and 2002 show a small decrease in the number of deaths in those years compared to 2000."<ref>Karl Eschbach, [[Jacqueline Hagan]], Nestor Rodríguez (2003): [http://www.uh.edu/cir/Deaths_during_migration.pdf Deaths during illegal migration: trends and policy implications in the new era of homeland security] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070206162336/http://www.uh.edu/cir/Deaths_during_migration.pdf |date=2007-02-06 }}. In ''In Defense of the Alien'', Vol. 26, pp. 37–52.</ref>
The number of deaths of illegal immigrants along the border has increased on a regular, yearly basis since the middle 1990s, particularly in the state of [[Arizona]].<ref name=Eschbach01/> As of summer 2006, tighter enforcement in Arizona has likely led to fewer deaths there, but border wide fatalities were approaching the record pace of 2005.<ref>San Diego Union-Tribune (July 22, 2006): [http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/mexico/tijuana/20060722-9999-1n22crossers.html Border deaths on record pace] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061027171142/http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/mexico/tijuana/20060722-9999-1n22crossers.html |date=2006-10-27 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20060722/images/border.pdf Apprehensions, Rescues, Deaths 2005–2006] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061102002203/http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20060722/images/border.pdf |date=2006-11-02 }}. [[The San Diego Union-Tribune]], July 27, 2006.</ref>
In 2012, the [[United States Border Patrol]] found the remains of 463 migrants in the U.S., of which 177 were discovered along the section of the border near Tucson, Arizona.<ref name="wola.org">Isacson, Adam. {{cite news|title=A Big Shift in Migration, and the Importance of Search and Rescue|url=http://www.wola.org/commentary/a_big_shift_in_migration_and_the_importance_of_search_and_rescue|date=11 December 2013|newspaper=[[Washington Office on Latin America]]|accessdate=20 February 2014}}</ref> The [[Rio Grande Valley]] of South Texas reported 150 migrant remains found, a jump from 2011 due to the increased numbers of Central American migrants.<ref name="wola.org"/><ref name="http">Isacson, Adam, Maureen Meyer and Ashley Davis. {{cite news|title=Border Security and Migration: A Report from Arizona|url=http://www.wola.org/publications/border_security_and_migration#remains|date=5 December 2013|newspaper=[[Washington Office on Latin America]]|accessdate=20 February 2014}}</ref>
===Exposure=== [[Hyperthermia]] is one of the most common causes of migrant border deaths.<ref name="Eschbach01"/>
===Drowning=== A common cause of immigrant border deaths is drowning in canals, ditches, and the [[Rio Grande]].<ref name="datb1">{{Citation|periodical=International Migration Review|publisher=The Center for Migration Studies of New York|last1=Eschbach|last2=Hagan|last3=Rodriguez|last4=Hernandez-Leon|last5=Bailey|first1=Karl|first2=Jacqueline|first3=Nestor|first4=Ruben|first5=Stanley|title=Death at the Border|volume=33|issue=2|year=1999}}</ref>
===Accidents=== Significant numbers of illegal immigrants die in [[car accident]]s and other accidental causes. According to a December 2006 cover story in the ''[[San Diego Reader]]'', "...traffic fatalities involving immigrants have more than doubled since 2003 as ''coyotes,'' or ''polleros'' – the guides leading migrants across the border – try other methods. On August 7, nine migrants died in a crash in the [[Yuma, Arizona|Yuma]] sector when the driver of a [[Chevrolet Suburban]] – in which 21 Mexicans were "stacked like cordwood<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/09/us/09crash.html|title=Risky Measures by Smugglers Increase Toll on Immigrants|first=Randal C.|last=Archibold|date=9 August 2006|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> – lost control after crossing a Border Patrol spike strip at high speed. This year the number killed in traffic accidents during illegal crossings is about 50."<ref>Stephen Dobyns. [http://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2006/dec/07/border-angels/ Border Angels]. [[San Diego Reader]], Dec 7, 2006.</ref>
In January 2003, two illegal immigrant passengers died when their truck crashed on [[Interstate 8]] while fleeing the Border Patrol, after a spike strip punctured a tire.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/metro/20030115-9999_7m15chase.html|title=Fleeing truck driver pleads not guilty in deaths of two|date=2003-01-15|first=Alex|last=Roth|accessdate=2008-07-31|newspaper=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031065305/http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/metro/20030115-9999_7m15chase.html|archivedate=2007-10-31|df=}}</ref> A week after the accident, a third person, Elvia Rumbo Leyva, died in the hospital.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/metro/20030717-9999_2m17smuggle.html|title=Woman says driver was prepared to die|date=2003-07-17|author=Soto, Onell R.|accessdate=2008-07-31|newspaper=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031065304/http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/metro/20030717-9999_2m17smuggle.html|archivedate=2007-10-31|df=}}</ref>
Close to one hundred illegal immigrants were struck and killed on [[San Diego County, California|San Diego County]] freeways over a five-year span in the late 1980s, prompting the creation of [[Immigration sign|a highway safety sign]] to caution drivers about migrants crossing the road.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20050410/news_1n10signs.html |title=Highway safety sign becomes running story on immigration |date=2005-04-10 |first=Leslie |last=Berestein |accessdate=2008-07-31 |newspaper=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724201725/http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20050410/news_1n10signs.html |archivedate=2008-07-24 |df= }}</ref>
===Incidents of Border Patrol use of force=== According to [[Rodolfo Acuña]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ideas_opinions/story/411102p-347789c.html |title=A day without immigrants? Yes|date=2006-04-23|accessdate=2008-07-31|author=Acuna, Rodolfo F.|publisher=[[Daily News (New York)]] |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060424152630/http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ideas_opinions/story/411102p-347789c.html |archivedate = 2006-04-24}}</ref> Professor Emeritus of Chicano Studies at [[California State University]], "Mexico's Ministry of Foreign Affairs reported 117 cases of human rights abuses by US officials against migrants from 1988 to 1990, including fourteen deaths. During the 1980s, Border Patrol agents shot dozens of people, killing eleven and permanently disabling ten."<ref name="laprensa">Rodolfo Acuña: [http://www.laprensa-sandiego.org/archieve/june16/analysis.htm Murder in Arizona . . . It's Only The Third World] [http://www.laprensa-sandiego.org/ La Prensa San Diego], [http://www.laprensa-sandiego.org/archieve/june16/000616.html Volume XXIV, Number 24, June 16, 2000]</ref>
On May 28, 1994, Martín García Martínez was shot by a Border Patrol agent at the San Ysidro port of entry. He died on July 3 as a result of his injuries.<ref>Human Rights Watch (1995): [https://www.hrw.org/reports/1995/Us1.htm Human Rights Abuses Along the U.S. Border with Mexico Persist Amid Climate of Impunity]</ref>
In May 2000, an illegal immigrant was shot in the shoulder by a border patrolman near Brownsville, Texas, and died later from the wounds.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/un-envoy-is-sent-to-investigate-rio-grande-shootings-by-posses-of-vigilante-ranchers-716094.html|title=UN envoy is sent to investigate Rio Grande shootings by posses of vigilante ranchers|author=McGirk, Jan|author2=Gumbel, Andrew|date=2000-05-24|accessdate=2008-07-31|publisher=[[The Independent]] | location=London}}</ref>
In January 2006, an eight-year veteran of the Border Patrol, fearful of stones which were being thrown at him <ref>{{Cite news|title=Border Shooting Death Raises U.S.-Mexico Tensions|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5168712|date=2006-01-23|work=[[All Things Considered]]|publisher=[[NPR]]|accessdate=2008-07-31|first=Carrie|last=Kahn}}</ref> shot Guillermo Martinez Rodriguez, a known people smuggler who had been detained 11 times prior.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://legacy.signonsandiego.com/news/mexico/tijuana/20060104-0936-mexico-us-immigration.html|title=U.S. official: Mexican shot after illegally crossing American border was known migrant smuggler|publisher=}}</ref> Rodriguez, with a gunshot to the back of his right shoulder, crossed back to Mexico and was taken to the Red Cross in Tijuana where he died twenty-five and a half hours later from the injury.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sre.gob.mx/english/events/guillermo_case.htm|title=Secretaría de Relaciones Exteriores – Gobierno |publisher=}}</ref> Under the Border Patrol's use-of-force guidelines, agents are permitted to employ lethal force against rock throwers if they pose a threat.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/feb/16/local/me-shoot16 | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Agent cleared in 2005 border shooting | first=Richard | last=Marosi | date=2008-02-16 | accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref> Large rocks have seriously injured many agents and many agents have resorted to wearing riot gear as a result.
In January 2007, border patrol agent Nicholas Corbett shot and killed Francisco Javier Domínguez Rivera.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,243891,00.html|title=FBI to Investigate Shooting Death of Mexican Immigrant by Border Patrol in U.S.|publisher=[[Fox News Channel]]|date=2007-01-16|accessdate=2008-07-31}}</ref> after the latter tried to smash his head with a rock according to the officer's lawyer.<ref name="douglasdispatch.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.douglasdispatch.com/articles/2010/01/06/news/doc4b43bdf2e0ea6468769878.txt|title=Making sense of filings in legal case against agent who shot immigrant|first=Jonathon ShacatWick News|last=Service|publisher=}}</ref> After the agent was acquitted of wrongdoing, a civil suit was filed on behalf of Rivera's parents. This civil suit claimed that the United States government was responsible for wrongful death of Rivera due to the fact that the agent was performing his official duty.<ref name="douglasdispatch.com"/> Mexico lodged an official protest with the United States over the death stating its "firm condemnation" and "serious concern over the recurrence of this type of incident." The protest demanded an exhaustive investigation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/mexico/20070116-1941-mexico-usa-.html|title=Mexico protests death of illegal immigrant in U.S.|date=2007-01-16|publisher=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090705034621/http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/mexico/20070116-1941-mexico-usa-.html|archivedate=2009-07-05|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/mexico/20070122-1526-mexico-migrantkilled.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120910005934/http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/mexico/20070122-1526-mexico-migrantkilled.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-09-10|title=Relatives bury Mexican migrant shot by Border Patrol in Arizona|date=2007-01-22|accessdate=2008-07-31|publisher=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]]}}</ref> Though the incident was recorded by surveillance cameras, the recording was not very clear.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Border Patrol video camera recorded immigrant's shooting|url=http://www.tucsoncitizen.com/ss/local/39205.php|date=2007-01-19|accessdate=2008-07-31|publisher=[[Tucson Citizen]]}}</ref>
On May 28, 2010, Anastasio Rojas, a 42-year-old Mexican migrant worker, was [[taser|tased]] and beaten at the San Ysidro border crossing by more than a dozen Customs and Border Protection officers.<ref name="AP">{{cite news|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2010/jun/08/mexico-anger-high-as-us-border-patrol-kills-teen/|title=Mexico anger high as US Border Patrol kills teen|accessdate=3 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Popescu |first=Roxana |title=Deadly patrols: Political climate limits prosecutions in border shootings |url=http://openchannel.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2012/07/19/12830534-deadly-patrols-political-climate-limits-prosecutions-in-border-shootings?lite |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130103230804/http://openchannel.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2012/07/19/12830534-deadly-patrols-political-climate-limits-prosecutions-in-border-shootings?lite |dead-url=yes |archive-date=3 January 2013 |accessdate=22 July 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=FLORIDO|first=ADRIAN|title=Calls For Justice In Tasing Death|url=http://www.kpbs.org/news/2012/may/04/calls-justice-tasing-death-hands-border-agents/|accessdate=22 July 2012}}</ref> Rojas' death was featured on the PBS News Magazine "Need to Know" in April 2012, in which several civilian eyewitnesses gave their testimony and provided two amateur videos of the event. According to the witnesses, he was facedown on the ground and handcuffed while he was being [[taser|tased]] and beaten, all the while being surrounded by twelve officers. His pleas for help is clearly audible on the amateur footage. In the hours before Rojas' death, he had tried to file a complaint against a Border Patrol officer for kicking his injured ankle, that officer and another officer would later drive Rojas to the border alone at night, soon after Rojas sustained fatal injuries.<ref name="PB">{{cite web|title=PBS Need to Know, Crossing the Line|url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/need-to-know/security/video-first-look-crossing-the-line/13597/ |accessdate=22 July 2012}}</ref> Since the initial broadcast of "Need to Know", 16 members of congress have demanded a justice department investigation into Anastasio Rojas' death while in Border Patrol's custody, which is currently under way.<ref>{{cite web|title=PBS Need to Know, Crossing the Line part 2|url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/need-to-know/video/need-to-know-july-20-2012-crossing-the-line-part-2/14271/ |accessdate=22 July 2012}}</ref> He leaves behind a wife and five children.<ref name="PB" />
On June 2010, a 15-year-old Mexican citizen was shot to death on the Mexican side of the border near El Paso, Texas. The U.S. Border Patrol reported that the officers responded to a group of suspected illegal immigrants who were throwing rocks at them. President [[Felipe Calderón]] criticized the shooting by stating that "the use of firearms to repel attacks with stones represents disproportionate use of force".<ref name="AP" /><ref name="Dentron">{{cite news|url=http://www.dentonrc.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/texassouthwest/stories/DN-borderpatrol_09tex.ART.State.Edition1.2949f5e.html|title=Mexican teen shot to death by U.S. Border Patrol agent|accessdate=3 September 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130121103112/http://www.dentonrc.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/texassouthwest/stories/DN-borderpatrol_09tex.ART.State.Edition1.2949f5e.html|archivedate=21 January 2013|df=}}</ref>
===Vigilante killings=== According to [[Time (magazine)|''Time'' Magazine]], in the first half of 2000, three immigrants were killed and seven others wounded in showdowns on the U.S. side of the border.<ref>Time McGirk: [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,997279,00.html Border Clash]. [[Time Magazine]], June 26, 2000.</ref><ref>The Independent (May 20, 2000): [https://archive.is/20070629060656/http://news.independent.co.uk/world/americas/article276502.ece Mexico asks UN for help to stop ranch 'posses' hunting migrants]{{cite web |url=http://www.commondreams.org/headlines/052000-02.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070204055947/http://www.commondreams.org/headlines/052000-02.htm |archivedate=2007-02-04 |df= }}</ref>
In 2000, the [[United Nations]] opened an investigation into vigilante killings of migrants crossing Mexico's border with the U.S., dispatching a senior UN investigator to the border country close to where Sam Blackwood, a 74-year-old rancher, was charged with killing [[El Inmigrante|Eusebio de Haro]],<ref>The Independent (24 May 2000): [http://news.independent.co.uk/world/americas/article276503.ece UN envoy is sent to investigate Rio Grande shootings by posses of vigilante ranchers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071001083041/http://news.independent.co.uk/world/americas/article276503.ece |date=2007-10-01 }}</ref> an unarmed Mexican he tried to subdue for the border patrol and fatally shot in the back of the thigh{{clarify|date=February 2014}} after pursuing him a quarter mile down the road in his truck.<ref>John Gonzalez. [https://archive.is/20120718061938/http://search.chron.com/chronicle/openDocument.do?docRef=archive_2001_3329174&selectedPath=Archives Rancher Convicted in Immigrant's Death]. [[Houston Chronicle]] ([[Reuters]]), August 25, 2001. [http://www.commondreams.org/headlines01/0825-01.htm Alternative source] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070614025708/http://www.commondreams.org/headlines01/0825-01.htm |date=2007-06-14 }}.</ref><ref>Pauline Arrillaga: [http://www.seacoastonline.com/2000news/8_20_w1.htm Border war] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051206094614/http://www.seacoastonline.com/2000news/8_20_w1.htm |date=2005-12-06 }}. Associated Press. August 20, 2000</ref>
===Intentional killings=== On February 8, 2007, four gunmen of unknown nationality opened fire on a truck carrying illegal immigrants in the [[Ironwood Forest National Monument]], killing two men and a 15-year-old girl.<ref name="slain">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/09/us/09immig.html|title=Illegal Immigrants Slain in an Attack in Arizona|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2007-02-09|accessdate=2008-07-31|author=Archibold, Randal C.}}</ref>
==Impact on border communities==
The impact of migrant deaths on border communities can be difficult for small towns on the U.S. side, which have found themselves with hundreds of remains to identify and bury, at a cost of hundreds of thousands of dollars.<ref>{{cite news|title=Immigrant deaths surge in South Texas county|url=http://lubbockonline.com/texas/2012-12-31/immigrant-deaths-surge-south-texas-county#.UwZmUmJdXD0|date=21 December 2012|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=20 February 2014}}</ref> In November 2013, the Office of the Medical Examiner in Pima County, Arizona, had 871 cases of unidentified remains dating as far back as the 1990s.<ref name="http"/> Relief groups often aid migrants traveling along the border. A Mexican federal task force known as Grupos Betas protects migrants from crime while the migrants make the journey north.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://articles.latimes.com/1992-03-10/news/mn-3541_1_grupo-beta|title = Reducing the Misery at the Border : Immigration: Grupo Beta is an elite Mexican multi-agency force with the task of protecting migrants. It has cut violence and improved relations between U.S. and Mexico.|last = Rotellafirst = Sebastian|date = 1992-03-10|newspaper = Los Angeles Times|issn = 0458-3035|access-date = 2016-03-11}}</ref> Other groups such as '[[No More Deaths]]' provide migrants with humanitarian assistance and members participate in 'desert runs' to search for migrants in need of help.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nomoredeaths.org/index.php/Information/history-and-mission-of-no-more-deaths.html |title=History and Mission of No More Deaths {{!}} Information |date=2010-06-11 |access-date=2016-03-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100611195214/http://nomoredeaths.org/index.php/Information/history-and-mission-of-no-more-deaths.html |archivedate=June 11, 2010 }}</ref>
==International consequences==
The deaths have caused tension between the United States and other countries, particularly Mexico and the countries of [[Central America]],{{citation needed|date = February 2014}} from where a majority of illegal immigrants that enter the United States through the Southwestern borders come. Foreign consulates across the Southwest United States, in particular those of [[Latin America]]n countries, have condemned the deaths of illegal immigrants across the border.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sre.gob.mx/english/events/guillermo_case.htm|title=Follow-up to the Guillermo Martínez Rodríguez case|date=2006-01-05|accessdate=2008-07-31|publisher=Secretaría de Relaciones Exteriores | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927212556/http://www.sre.gob.mx/english/events/guillermo_case.htm| archivedate = September 27, 2007}}</ref>

page.title: Murder of Diane and Alan Scott Johnson

revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=November 2011}} The '''murder of Diane and Alan Scott Johnson''' occurred on September 2, 2003. They were shot to death in their [[Bellevue, Idaho]], home by their 16-year-old daughter Sarah Marie Johnson.<!--She was born January 24, 1987. She grew up in the upper-class Idaho suburb of [[Bellevue, Idaho|Bellevue]] and attended [[Wood River High School (Idaho)|Wood River High School]] in [[Hailey, Idaho|Hailey]].--><ref name=prime>{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/TheLaw/story?id=3451371&page=1&singlePage=true#.TrLDGfQr2so |title=Primetime Crime: Teen Charged With Parents' Gruesome Murder |accessdate=2011-11-02 |quote=In late June, judges in the Idaho Supreme Court upheld a jury verdict that Sarah had brutally murdered her parents in 2003, a case solved by DNA and the then-16-year-old's suspicious behavior shortly after the bodies were found. ... |publisher=[[ABC Primetime]]}}</ref>
== Perpetrator == '''Sarah Marie Johnson''' was born January 24, 1987.<ref>[https://krazykillers.wordpress.com/2011/09/01/sarah-johnson-peculiar-parracide/ Killers Without Conscience]</ref> She grew up in the Idaho city of [[Bellevue, Idaho|Bellevue]], and attended [[Wood River High School (Idaho)|Wood River High School]] in [[Hailey, Idaho|Hailey]].<ref name="prime"/>
== History == On September 2, 2003, Alan Scott Johnson and Diane Johnson were shot to death in their [[Bellevue, Idaho]], home. Alan was shot twice in the chest, while Diane was shot in the head. Their daughter, Sarah Johnson, was found guilty of their murder. Sarah was 16 years old at the time. Her apparent motive was her parents' prohibiting her from [[dating]] 19-year-old Bruno Santos.<ref name=prime/>
At approximately 6:20 am on September 2, 2003, Johnson took the murder weapon, a [[Winchester rifle]] from the guest house. The tenant of the house had left for [[Boise, Idaho]], and had not planned on returning for a week or so. She then walked into her parents' bedroom and shot her sleeping mother in the head, whereupon she walked into the bathroom and shot her father in the chest, right above the heart, while he was showering. DNA evidence was presented at trial from a discarded bathrobe and a [[latex glove]] that police found in the garbage can in front of the house. It contained the DNA of both victims and Sarah. Along with the robe and latex glove was a [[leather glove]] that had [[gunshot residue]] on it. In Johnson's bedroom investigators located the other leather glove that belonged to the pair.<ref>http://blog.heritage.org/2009/10/23/adult-time-for-adult-crime-sarah-johnson/ Adult Time for Adult Crime: Sarah Johnson</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Englert|first1=Rod|last2=Passero|first2=Kathy|last3=Rule|first3=Ann|coauthors= |title=Blood Secrets: Chronicles of a Crime Scene Reconstructionist|page=251 |quote=Sarah's father, Alan Johnson, lay facedown and naked on the floor nearby, ... DNA tests showed the blood spatter belonged to both Diane and Alan Johnson. ... Police traced the murder weapon, a .264 Winchester Magnum rifle found lying ... | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qClDKpG_vikC&pg=PA251&lpg=PA251&dq=Alan+Johnson+and+Diane+Johnson+murder&source=bl&ots=0MVWaIMjfP&sig=49iJiHxDwufJhogNF_g_VWXyis4&hl=en&ei=EMSyTpSIAoni0QH0seTGBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CDsQ6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q=Alan%20Johnson%20and%20Diane%20Johnson%20murder&f=false |isbn= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Expert: Daughter's DNA found on evidence at slain parents' home |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2005-02-18/justice/johnson_1_dna-samples-gunshot-residue-trace-evidence-examiner?_s=PM:LAW |quote=In a garbage can outside the home of Alan and Diane Johnson, detectives found a latex glove, a left-handed leather glove, and a blood-spattered pink bathrobe belonging to their daughter, Sarah Johnson, who was 16 at the time. |work=[[CNN]] |date=February 18, 2005 |accessdate=2011-11-02 }}</ref>
Johnson was found guilty of the murders of her parents by an [[Ada County, Idaho]], jury on March 16, 2005.<ref>{{cite web |author=Greg Stahl |url=http://www.mtexpress.com/index2.php?issue_date=03-18-2005&ID=2005102122 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050319094937/http://www.mtexpress.com/index2.php?issue_date=03-18-2005&ID=2005102122 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2005-03-19 |title=Idaho Mountain Express: Johnson guilty of killing parents - March 18, 2005 |publisher=Mtexpress.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-01 }}</ref> She was sentenced to two concurrent life terms plus fifteen years for a firearm enhancement. The [[Idaho Supreme Court]] upheld her conviction.
In 2012, Johnson's lawyer filed petition for a new trial, charging that she had ineffective legal counsel in the murder trial.<ref>[http://magicvalley.com/news/local/crime-and-courts/sarah-johnson-again-seeks-new-trial-for-parents-murder/article_ef90d6ba-948f-11e1-acca-0019bb2963f4.html]</ref> In October 2014, the request was denied.<ref>[http://www.ktvb.com/story/news/crime/2014/10/31/judge-denies-johnson-new-trial/18244987/]</ref>
==Media== The case has been featured on [[Investigation Discovery|Discovery ID's]] ''[[Solved (TV series)|Solved]]'' series and ''[[Deadly Women]]'' series, the ''[[Suburban Secrets]]'' documentary show, the [[Spike (TV channel)|Spike TV]] reality show ''[[Murder (U.S. TV program)|Murder]]'', ''[[Snapped]]'' on the [[Oxygen (TV channel)|Oxygen Network]] and [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''Primetime: Crime'' (edited into an episode of Investigation Discovery's 20/20 on ID in 2014).<ref name=prime/>
This case also appeared on an episode of ''[[Forensic Files]]'' on [[TruTV]] and on [[E!|E!'s]] ''Too Young to Kill: 15 Shocking Crimes'' at #9. This case was also featured in episode #067 of the podcast ''Small Town Murder.''Her story also appears in episode 19 of the Netflix series Killer Women.
==See also== *[[Parricide]]
==References== {{reflist}}

[[Category:2003 murders in the United States]] [[Category:Murder committed by minors]] [[Category:Matricides]] [[Category:Patricides]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Idaho]] [[Category:People murdered in Idaho]] [[Category:Deaths by person in the United States]] [[Category:Violence in Idaho]] [[Category:2003 in Idaho]] [[Category:Bellevue, Idaho]] [[Category:American murder victims]]

{{redirect|Melanie Hall|the Australian wheelchair basketballer|Melanie Hall (basketball)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox person |name = Melanie Hall |image = Melanie Hall.png |caption = Melanie Hall |birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1970|08|20}} |birth_place = England |disappeared_date = 9 June 1996 (aged 25) |disappeared_place = [[Bath, Somerset]], UK |death_date = [[Declared death in absentia|Declared legally dead]] 17 November 2004 |body_discovered = 5 October 2009
[[Thornbury, Gloucestershire]], UK |residence = |education = |occupation = Clerical officer |employer = [[Royal United Hospital]] |father = Steve Hall |mother = Patricia Hall |alma mater = [[University of Bath]] |known for = [[Murder]] victim |home_town = }} '''Melanie Hall''' (20 August 1970 – disappeared 9 June 1996; [[Declared death in absentia|declared legally dead]] 17 November 2004{{cite news|title=Melanie declared dead 8 years after vanishing from nightclub|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1476893/Melanie-declared-dead-8-years-after-vanishing-from-nightclub.html|work=[[Daily Telegraph]]|location=London|date=18 November 2004|first=Richard|last=Savill|accessdate=12 July 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140304030712/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1476893/Melanie-declared-dead-8-years-after-vanishing-from-nightclub.html#|archive-date=4 March 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}) was a British hospital clerical officer from [[Bradford on Avon]], who disappeared on 9 June 1996, following a night out at the Cadillacs nightclub in [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]. It was not until 5 October 2009 that her partial remains were discovered, after a plastic bin bag containing human bones was located by a workman on the [[M5 motorway]] near [[Thornbury, South Gloucestershire|Thornbury]], [[South Gloucestershire]]. The bones, which included a [[human pelvis|pelvis]], [[femur|thigh bone]] and [[human skull|skull]], were analysed and identified as belonging to Melanie Hall on 7 October 2009. It was determined that Hall had suffered severe fractures to her skull and face, and had been tied up with rope, although a definitive cause of death could not be established.{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/crime-courts/murder-victim-melanie-hall-was-bound-with-blue-rope-after-killer-her-skull-and-jaw-1.926011|title=Murder victim Melanie Hall was bound with blue rope after killer broke her skull and jaw|date=13 October 2009|work=[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]|accessdate=11 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111093101/http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/crime-courts/murder-victim-melanie-hall-was-bound-with-blue-rope-after-killer-her-skull-and-jaw-1.926011#|archive-date=11 January 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Over the years, various people have been arrested but subsequently released. ==Background== Hall was described by her parents as a "young, vibrant daughter". She had graduated from the [[University of Bath]] in 1995, Hall's mother, Pat Hall, said graduation had been a "cherished" dream of Melanie's for four years.{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisbath.co.uk/news/Family-s-years-heartache/article-1402672-detail/article.html|title=Family's years of heartache|date=8 October 2009|work=The Bath Chronicle|accessdate=8 October 2009|location=Bath|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091011093802/http://www.thisisbath.co.uk/news/Family-s-years-heartache/article-1402672-detail/article.html#|archive-date=11 October 2009|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Melanie Hall worked as a clerical officer at Bath's [[Royal United Hospital]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/8296600.stm|title=Woman's bones left 'like garbage' |date=8 October 2009|publisher=BBC|accessdate=8 October 2009}} Her father, Stephen Hall, has served [[Bath City F.C.|Bath City Football Club]] as a chairman. ==Disappearance== Hall had arranged to stay with her boyfriend Philip Karlbaum on 8 June and her mother dropped her off at his home.{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/homepage/Melanie-Hall-mystery-baffled-police/article-1400117-detail/article.html|title=Melanie Hall: A mystery which has baffled police|date=8 October 2009|publisher=Bristol Evening Post|accessdate=8 October 2009|location=Bristol|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091012152916/http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/homepage/Melanie-Hall-mystery-baffled-police/article-1400117-detail/article.html|archive-date=12 October 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} On the night of 8 June 1996 Hall went to Cadillacs nightclub in Bath with Karlbaum and another couple. Hall was reported as having had an argument with Karlbaum, and he left the club "upset" after he allegedly saw her dancing with another man. Hall was last seen sitting on a stool in the club at around 1.10am on 9 June 1996.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/6270860/Melanie-Hall-timeline.html|title=Melanie Hall: timeline|date=8 October 2009|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=8 October 2009|location=London|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091011071908/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/6270860/Melanie-Hall-timeline.html#|archive-date=11 October 2009|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/8295701.stm|title=Timeline: Melanie Hall disappearance|date=7 October 2009|publisher=BBC|accessdate=8 October 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170806020945/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/8295701.stm#|archive-date=6 August 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} She was reported missing on 11 June 1996 by her parents after she failed to turn up for work. Karlbaum described his devastation at her disappearance on 17 June 1996. [[Avon and Somerset Constabulary|Avon and Somerset police]] launched several searches of the [[River Avon (Bristol)|River Avon]] after her disappearance and interviewed thousands of clubbers and taxi drivers. A [[pound sterling|£]]10,000 reward was offered for information,{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/2842645.stm|title=Melanie Hall: the background|date=14 March 2003|publisher=BBC|accessdate=8 October 2009}} the BBC show ''[[Crimewatch]]'' and ''[[Crimestoppers]]'' both made appeals to the public for information, as did Hall's sister Dominique,{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/sister-of-melanie-hall-appeals-for-help-from-public-1337759.html|title=Sister of Melanie Hall appeals for help from public|date=19 June 1996|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=24 October 2009|location=London|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104191300/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/sister-of-melanie-hall-appeals-for-help-from-public-1337759.html#|archive-date=4 November 2012|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} but no trace of Hall was found. Hall was [[Declared death in absentia|declared legally dead]] on 17 November 2004. ===Discovery of remains=== On 5 October 2009, a motorway worker found a plastic bin bag containing bones while he was clearing a vegetation patch on a slip road at Junction 14 of the [[M5 motorway]]. The bones in the bag included a skull, pelvis and thigh bone and further remains were found buried and spread around the field by the side of the motorway. Police confirmed that the remains were human, and they showed a piece of jewellery found at the site to Mr and Mrs Hall, who confirmed that it had belonged to their daughter.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/8296122.stm|title=Jewellery 'key' in M5 bones case |date=8 October 2009 |publisher=BBC|accessdate=8 October 2009}} Despite this, police refused to confirm that the body was that of Miss Hall until a post-mortem had been carried out.{{cite web|url=http://www.bristol247.com/2009/10/07/police-refuse-to-confirm-bones-link-to-missing-melanie/|title=Police refuse to confirm bones link to missing Melanie|date=7 October 2009|publisher=Bristol247|accessdate=8 October 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091011074315/http://www.bristol247.com/2009/10/07/police-refuse-to-confirm-bones-link-to-missing-melanie/|archivedate=11 October 2009|df=dmy-all}} The remains were formally identified as being Hall's through dental records on 7 October. She had incurred severe blunt trauma to her head resulting in a fractured skull, cheekbone and jaw. Hall had also been tied up with a blue rope. Hall's parents launched a fresh appeal on 8 October for anyone with information to come forward, while Avon and Somerset CID DS Mike Britton stated that he was staying on after his retirement to continue working on the Hall disappearance, codenamed Operation Denmark, having spent 13 years on the case.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/somerset/8323755.stm|title=CID man holds retirement for case |date=24 October 2009|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=24 October 2009}}{{Cite news|title=Murder of Melanie Hall|url=http://www.avonandsomerset.police.uk/newsroom/special_appeals/melanie-hall/|work=[[Avon and Somerset Constabulary]]|accessdate=16 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121016122530/http://avonandsomerset.police.uk/newsroom/special_appeals/melanie-hall/|archivedate=16 October 2012|df=dmy-all}} On 29 October 2009, police announced that three keys to a [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] vehicle, possibly a [[Ford Transit|Transit]], [[Ford Fiesta|Fiesta]] or [[Ford Escort (Europe)|Escort]] had been found near the body, and that they were working with Ford to try to identify the vehicle. ''[[Crimewatch]]'' also launched a fresh appeal for information, which resulted in more than 200 phone calls from the public. The reward for information leading to arrest was also increased to £20,000.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/8331294.stm|title=Hundreds contact M5 murder police|date=29 October 2009|publisher=BBC|accessdate=29 October 2009}} ===Arrests=== In 2003, police arrested two men in connection with Hall's disappearance but they were released without charge after police searched buildings and a field near Bath.{{cite news|title=Second man arrested over Melanie Hall murder|first=Nick|last=Collins|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/7974166/Second-man-arrested-over-Melanie-Hall-murder.html|date=31 August 2010|work=[[Daily Telegraph]]|location=London|accessdate=12 September 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160313021027/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/7974166/Second-man-arrested-over-Melanie-Hall-murder.html#|archive-date=13 March 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} In 2009, a 37-year-old man confessed his involvement in Hall's murder to police in [[Greater Manchester]], but was eliminated from the inquiry after undergoing [[Psychiatry|psychiatric tests]].{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article6867555.ece|title=Arrest in Melanie Hall murder was false alarm, but DNA hope remains|date=9 October 2009|accessdate=12 September 2010|work=[[The Times]]|location=London|first=Philippe|last=Naughton}} In July 2010, a 38-year-old man from Bath was arrested on suspicion of Hall's murder and subsequently released on [[bail]].{{cite news|url=http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/Melanie-murder-man-38-arrested/story-11271279-detail/story.html|title=Melanie murder: man, 38, arrested|newspaper=[[Bristol Evening Post]]|date=2 July 2010|accessdate=12 July 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130421115844/http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/Melanie-murder-man-38-arrested/story-11271279-detail/story.html|archive-date=21 April 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10478248|title=Man held over Melanie Hall M5 murder inquiry|date=1 July 2010|accessdate=12 September 2010|work=[[BBC News]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100903172841/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10478248#|archive-date=3 September 2010|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} In August 2010, a 39-year-old man from [[Wiltshire]] was arrested by police on suspicion of murder after handing himself in at a police station in the [[Avon and Somerset Constabulary|Avon and Somerset]] area.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/sep/01/melanie-hall-murder-inquiry-arrest|first=Steven|last=Morris|title=Man held in Melanie Hall murder inquiry|date=1 September 2010|accessdate=12 September 2010|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306032014/http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/sep/01/melanie-hall-murder-inquiry-arrest#|archive-date=6 March 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The man was subsequently released on bail.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-11157452|title=Melanie Hall murder police release Wiltshire man|location=Bristol|date=1 September 2010|work=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=12 September 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100904005634/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-11157452#|archive-date=4 September 2010|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} In October 2013, police said that they had found a white [[Volkswagen Golf]] car connected to their inquiries, and had received relevant information about the rope used to tie up Hall's body.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-24372488|title=Melanie Hall murder police receive 'significant information'|location=Bristol|date=3 October 2013|work=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=25 November 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006221520/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-24372488#|archive-date=6 October 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} On 25 November 2013, it was reported that a 44-year-old man had been arrested at an address in Bath, on suspicion of murder. The man was released on bail until 19 December, and a property at Roundhill Park, [[Whiteway, Bath|Whiteway]], was searched.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-25087061|title=Melanie Hall M5 murder inquiry: Man from Bath arrested|location=Bristol|date=25 November 2013|work=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=25 November 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131126045432/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-25087061#|archive-date=26 November 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} On 28 November 2014 it was reported that there was insufficient evidence to charge the suspect.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-30252287|title=Melanie Hall murder: 'Insufficient evidence' to charge suspect|author=|date=28 November 2014|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk|access-date=20 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160718061542/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-30252287#|archive-date=18 July 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} On 23 June 2016, a 45-year-old man was arrested following retrieval of DNA from where Hall's remains were discovered,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-somerset-36622997|title=Melanie Hall murder: Man, 45, arrested|author=|date=24 June 2016|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com|access-date=20 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161108192628/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-somerset-36622997#|archive-date=8 November 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} and released on bail a few days later.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-somerset-36633856|title=Melanie Hall murder suspect bailed|author=|date=26 June 2016|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk|access-date=20 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160911165629/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-somerset-36633856#|archive-date=11 September 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} ===Links to other cases=== Police have not ruled out links with the murder of estate agent [[Suzy Lamplugh]] (who disappeared in July 1986 and whose body has never been found) and the case of a serial sex attacker in Bath, nicknamed the "[[Batman rapist]]" after he left a baseball cap bearing a ''[[Batman]]'' logo at the scene of one attack.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/fresh-police-plea-in-melanie-hall-murder-probe-1937162.html|title=Fresh police plea in Melanie Hall murder probe|first=Jamie|last=Grierson|date=6 April 2010|accessdate=12 September 2010|work=[[The Independent]]|location=London|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100409072805/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/fresh-police-plea-in-melanie-hall-murder-probe-1937162.html#|archive-date=9 April 2010|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1372014/Leaflets-sent-to-25000-homes-in-rape-inquiry.html|title=Leaflets sent to 25,000 homes in rape inquiry|date=27 October 2000|accessdate=12 September 2010|first=John|last=Steele|work=[[Daily Telegraph]]|location=London|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140514012732/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1372014/Leaflets-sent-to-25000-homes-in-rape-inquiry.html#|archive-date=14 May 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The unknown assailant is known to have attempted to [[Carjacking|carjack]] a woman at knifepoint, leaving her wounded when she fought back and managed to escape, in the same area of the city a few hours before Hall was abducted.{{cite news|title=Riddler rapist's evil game of cap and mouse|work=[[News of the World]]|location=London|date=14 February 1999|first=Ian|last=Edmondson|page=42}}{{cite news|last=Young|first=Sydney|title=Please find my perfect daughter|newspaper=[[Daily Mirror]]|location=London|date=12 June 1996|page=8}} It has also been suggested that there may be a link between Hall's murder and [[Levi Bellfield]], who is serving life imprisonment with a [[whole life order]] for three murders committed between 2002 and 2004.{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/levi-bellfield-could-questioned-over-7274166|title=Levi Bellfield 'could be questioned over unsolved murder of Melanie Hall'|first=Natalie|last=Evans|date=30 January 2016|website=mirror.co.uk|access-date=2 April 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180904153924/https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/levi-bellfield-could-questioned-over-7274166#|archive-date=4 September 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} ==See also== *[[List of people who disappeared]] *[[List of unsolved murders in the United Kingdom]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/8295701.stm Timeline: Melanie Hall disappearance] from [[BBC News]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Hall, Melanie}} [[Category:1990s missing person cases]] [[Category:1996 crimes in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1996 in England]] [[Category:2009 in England]] [[Category:Crime in Gloucestershire]] [[Category:Crime in Somerset]] [[Category:Deaths by person]] [[Category:Formerly missing people found dead]] [[Category:June 1996 crimes]] [[Category:June 1996 events in Europe]] [[Category:Missing person cases in England]] [[Category:Murder in 1996]] [[Category:Unsolved murders in the United Kingdom]]

{{Pfam_box|Symbol=|Name=|image=|width=|caption=|Pfam=PF01566|InterPro=|SMART=|Prosite=|SCOP=|TCDB=2.A.55|OPM family=64|OPM protein=4wgv|PDB=}} '''Natural resistance-associated macrophage proteins''' (NRAMPs) are members of the '''metal ion (Mn<sup>2+</sup>-iron) transporter family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.55 TC# 2.A.55]). The NRAMP family is a member of the large [[APC Superfamily]] of secondary carriers.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Vastermark A, Wollwage S, Houle ME, Rio R, Saier MH | title = Expansion of the APC superfamily of secondary carriers | journal = Proteins | volume = 82 | issue = 10 | pages = 2797–811 | date = October 2014 | pmid = 25043943 | pmc = 4177346 | doi = 10.1002/prot.24643 }}</ref> Homologues of this family are found in various [[yeast]]s, [[plant]]s, [[animal]]s, [[archaea]], and [[Gram-negative bacteria|Gram-negative]] and [[Gram-positive bacteria]] termed "natural resistance-associated" [[macrophage]] proteins because one of the animal homologues plays a role in resistance to intracellular bacterial [[pathogen]]s such as ''[https://microbewiki.kenyon.edu/index.php/Salmonella_enterica_serovar_Typhi Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium]'', ''[[Leishmania donovani]]'' and ''[[Mycobacterium bovis]]''. The natural history of ''SLC11'' genes in vertebrates has been discussed by Neves et al. (2011).<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Neves JV, Wilson JM, Kuhl H, Reinhardt R, Castro LF, Rodrigues PN | title = Natural history of SLC11 genes in vertebrates: tales from the fish world | journal = BMC Evolutionary Biology | volume = 11 | pages = 106 | date = April 2011 | pmid = 21501491 | pmc = 3103463 | doi = 10.1186/1471-2148-11-106 }}</ref> Proposed to be a distant member of the [[APC Superfamily]], several human pathologies may result from defects in NRAMP-dependent Fe<sup>2+</sup> or Mn<sup>2+</sup> transport, including iron overload, neurodegenerative diseases and innate susceptibility to infectious diseases.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Cellier MF | title = Nramp: from sequence to structure and mechanism of divalent metal import | journal = Current Topics in Membranes | volume = 69 | pages = 249–93 | date = 2012-01-01 | pmid = 23046654 | doi = 10.1016/B978-0-12-394390-3.00010-0 }}</ref>
==NRAMP2== {{Main|DMT1}} Humans and rodents possess two distinct NRAMPs. The broad specificity NRAMP2 (DMT1), which transports a range of divalent metal cations, transports Fe<sup>2+</sup> and H<sup>+</sup> with a 1:1 stoichiometry and apparent affinities of 6 μm and about 1 μm, respectively. Variable H<sup>+</sup>:Fe<sup>2+</sup> stoichiometry has also been reported. The order of substrate preference for NRAMP2 is:
Fe<sup>2+</sup>> Zn<sup>2+</sup>> Mn<sup>2+</sup>> Co<sup>2+</sup>> Ca<sup>2+</sup>> Cu<sup>2+</sup>> Ni<sup>2+</sup>> Pb<sup>2+</sup>
Many of these ions can inhibit iron absorption. Mutation of NRAMP2 in rodents leads to defective [[Endosome|endosomal]] iron export within the ferritin cycle, impaired intestinal iron absorption and [[microcytic anemia]]. Symptoms of Mn<sup>2+</sup> deficiency are also seen. It is found in apical membranes of intestinal epithelial cells but also in late [[endosome]]s and [[lysosome]]s.
==NRAMP1== {{Main|SLC11A1}} In contrast to the widely expressed NRAMP2, NRAMP1 is expressed primarily in [[macrophage]]s and [[monocyte]]s and appears to have a preference for Mn<sup>2+</sup> rather than Fe<sup>2+</sup>. NRAMP1 ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.55.2.3 TC# 2.A.55.2.3]) has been reported to function by metal:H<sup>+</sup> antiport.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Techau ME, Valdez-Taubas J, Popoff JF, Francis R, Seaman M, Blackwell JM | title = Evolution of differences in transport function in Slc11a family members | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 282 | issue = 49 | pages = 35646–56 | date = December 2007 | pmid = 17932044 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M707057200 }}</ref> It is hypothesized that a deficiency for Mn<sup>2+</sup> or some other metal prevents the generation of reactive oxygenic and nitrogenic compounds that are used by macrophage to combat pathogens. This hypothesis is supported by studies on the bacterial NRAMP homologues which exhibit extremely high selectivity for Mn<sup>2+</sup> over Fe<sup>2+</sup>, Zn<sup>2+</sup> and other divalent cations.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Wei W, Chai T, Zhang Y, Han L, Xu J, Guan Z | title = The Thlaspi caerulescens NRAMP homologue TcNRAMP3 is capable of divalent cation transport | journal = Molecular Biotechnology | volume = 41 | issue = 1 | pages = 15–21 | date = January 2009 | pmid = 18663607 | doi = 10.1007/s12033-008-9088-x }}</ref> Regulation of these transporters in bacteria can occur through Fur, OxyR, and most commonly a DtxR homolog, MntR.
==Smf and other homologues== The Smf1 protein of ''[[Saccharomyces cerevisiae]]'' appears to catalyze high-affinity (''K<sub>M</sub>'' = 0.3 μm) Mn<sup>2+</sup> uptake while the closely related Smf2 protein may catalyze low affinity (''K<sub>M</sub>'' = 60 μm) Mn<sup>2+</sup> uptake in the same organism. Both proteins also mediate H<sup>+</sup>-dependent Fe<sup>2+</sup> uptake. These proteins are of 575 and 549 amino acyl residues in length and are predicted to have 8-12 transmembrane α-helical spanners. The ''E. coli'' homologue of 412 aas exhibits 11 putative and confirmed TMSs with the N-terminus in and the C-terminus out. The yeast proteins may be localized to the vacuole and/or the plasma membrane of the yeast cell. Indirect and some direct experiments suggest that they may be able to transport several heavy metals including Mn<sup>2+</sup>, Cu<sup>2+</sup>, Cd<sup>2+</sup> and Co<sup>2+</sup>. A third yeast protein, Smf3p, appears to be exclusively intracellular, possibly in the Golgi. NRAMP2 (''[[SLC11A2|Slc11A2]]'') of Homo sapiens ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.55.2.1 TC# 2.A.55.2.1]) has a 12 TMS topology with intracellular N- and C-termini. Two-fold structural symmetry in the arrangement of membrane helices for TM1-5 and TM6-10 (conserved Slc2 hydrophobic core) is suggested.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Czachorowski M, Lam-Yuk-Tseung S, Cellier M, Gros P | title = Transmembrane topology of the mammalian Slc11a2 iron transporter | journal = Biochemistry | volume = 48 | issue = 35 | pages = 8422–34 | date = September 2009 | pmid = 19621945 | pmc = 2736113 | doi = 10.1021/bi900606y }}</ref>
==Transport reaction== The generalized transport reaction catalyzed by NRAMP family proteins is:
Me<sup>2+</sup> (out) + H<sup>+</sup> (out) ⇌ Me<sup>2+</sup> (in) + H<sup>+</sup> (in).
== See also == * [[Solute carrier family]] * [[Ferroportin]]
== References == {{reflist}}
